questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug is associated with mutations in the KATG gene?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Isoniazid

 

Explanation:

Isoniazid (INH) resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis is commonly associated with mutations in the KATG gene, which encodes catalase-peroxidase.

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Isoniazid is a prodrug that requires activation by KatG (catalase-peroxidase enzyme).
    • Activated INH inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, disrupting the mycobacterial cell wall.
  • Mechanism of Resistance:
    • Mutations in KATG (especially Ser315Thr mutation) prevent isoniazid activation, leading to drug resistance.
    • Other mutations involve inhA gene (affecting the target enzyme enoyl-ACP reductase), leading to low-level resistance.

The mechanisms of resistance with Isoniazid are given below.

 

Mechanism of resistance

KatG gene mutation

INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the KATg gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug

KasA gene mutation

Component of cell wall mycolic acid

InhA gene overexpression

Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug)

 

Rifampicin (Option A) is incorrect because resistance is due to rpoB gene mutations, affecting RNA polymerase.

 

Moxifloxacin (Option C) is incorrect because fluoroquinolone resistance is linked to mutations in gyrA and gyrB genes, which encode DNA gyrase.

 

Ethambutol (Option D) is incorrect because resistance involves mutations in the embB gene, which encodes arabinosyl transferase, affecting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: A patient presents with arthritis, and arthroscopy reveals blackening of the joints. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Explanation:

  • Arthritis with joint blackening suggests alkaptonuria, a disorder caused by homogentisate oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which deposits in joints and cartilage.
  • Ochronosis (dark pigmentation): Homogentisic acid polymerizes and stains connective tissues, cartilage, and joints black, seen during arthroscopy.
  • Other features: Black urine (on standing due to oxidation), ochronotic pigmentation in the sclera and ear cartilage.

Alkaptonuria

Feature

Alkaptonuria (Homogentisate Oxidase Deficiency)

Deficient Enzyme

Homogentisate oxidase

Accumulated Metabolite

Homogentisic acid

Key Features

Black urine (on standing), ochronosis (dark connective tissue pigmentation), early-onset arthritis

Affected Areas

Joints, cartilage (ear, sclera, intervertebral discs)

Diagnosis

Urine darkening with alkalization, elevated homogentisic acid in urine

Treatment

Low-protein diet (restricting phenylalanine & tyrosine), vitamin C, symptomatic management
  • Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (Option B): Incorrect because its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), characterized by neurological symptoms, metabolic acidosis, and sweet-smelling urine, not arthritis.
  • Tyrosinase (Option C): Incorrect because its deficiency leads to albinism, causing hypopigmentation, not joint issues.
  • Fumarase (Option D): Incorrect because its deficiency affects the Krebs cycle, leading to metabolic acidosis, hypotonia, and neurological dysfunction, not ochronosis or arthritis.

questions.text: A young male presented with weakness in the lower half of the right side of his face, with drooping of the angle of his mouth. He is unable to raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

choices.text: Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on left side

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
 

Explanation:

 

  • Infranuclear facial palsy occurs when there is damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) after it exits the brainstem.
  • This leads to weakness or paralysis of the muscles of facial expression on the same side (right side in this case) of the face.
  • The patient will have difficulty raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes, and drooping of the mouth on the affected side. Both the upper and lower facial muscles are affected.

 

Facial nerve palsy:

 

Feature

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion (Supranuclear)

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion (Infranuclear)

Lesion Location

Motor cortex, connection from motor cortex to facial nucleus in pons

Facial nucleus, anywhere along CN VII

Affected Side

Contralateral

Ipsilateral

Muscles Involved

Lower muscles of facial expression

Upper and lower muscles of facial expression

Forehead Involved?

Spared, due to bilateral UMN innervation

Affected

Other Symptoms

Variable; depends on size of lesion

Incomplete eye closure (dry eyes, corneal ulceration), hyperacusis, loss of taste sensation to anterior tongue

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by food adulteration?
questions.solution:
Fluorosis is caused by excessive fluoride intake, primarily through drinking water, and not by food adulteration. Fluorosis is a chronic condition resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of fluoride, typically from geological sources in groundwater, rather than from any deliberate or accidental food contamination.

 

Epidemic dropsy (Option B): This condition is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with argemone oil (from Argemone mexicana seeds). The toxic alkaloids cause widespread edema, cardiac involvement, and glaucoma. This is a classic example of food adulteration causing significant public health problems.

 

Neurolathyrism (Option C): This is a neurological disorder caused by excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (grass pea) or when other pulses are adulterated with it, especially during times of famine. It results in spastic paraparesis of lower limbs. The condition is directly linked to food adulteration or contamination.


Endemic ascites (Option D): This condition is associated with food contamination or adulteration with pyrrolizidine alkaloids, typically found in certain plants. It can lead to veno-occlusive disease of the liver resulting in ascites.

questions.text: Which of the following is excreted in the urine of patients with pentosuria?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) L-Xylulose

 

Explanation:

L-Xylulose is excreted in the urine of patients with essential pentosuria, a rare benign metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of L-xylulose reductase. This leads to the accumulation and urinary excretion of L-xylulose, which can be mistaken for glucose in urine tests, but patients remain asymptomatic with no metabolic consequences.

 

Essential Pentosuria

Feature

Essential Pentosuria

Cause

Deficiency of L-xylulose reductase

Metabolic Effect

Increased excretion of L-xylulose in urine

Clinical Symptoms

None (asymptomatic)

Diagnosis

Urine sugar analysis + Chromatography

Treatment

No treatment needed


 

D-Ribose (Option B) is incorrect because it is a naturally occurring sugar involved in nucleotide metabolism and is not significantly excreted in pentosuria.

 

D-Ribulose (Option C) is incorrect because it is an intermediate in the pentose phosphate pathway but is not associated with pentosuria.

 

D-Lactose (Option D) is incorrect because lactose is a disaccharide and is not involved in pentose metabolism or pentosuria.

questions.text: Identify the treatment option with the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Type 3 tympanoplasty

 

Explanation:

Type 3 Tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus and incus are absent, but the stapes footplate is intact and mobile.

The tympanic membrane or graft is placed directly over the stapes head to allow sound conduction.

This technique helps improve hearing in cases of ossicular erosion due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), cholesteatoma, or trauma.

 

Types of Tympanoplasty (Wullstein's Classification):

 

Type

Description

Type I

Defect: perforated tympanic membrane.

Repaired using a graft. (myringoplasty) (Option A ruled out)

Type II

Defect: Eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus. (Option B ruled out)

Type III

Defect: Absence of malleus and incus.

Graft placed directly on stapes head (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

Type IV

Defect: Only the footplate of the stapes is present. It is exposed to the external ear.

A graft is placed between oval and round windows, allowing sound to act directly on the footplate and the round window is shielded. (Option D ruled out)

Type V

Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of melena that contains gastric mucosa and acute intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following structure was found, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Meckel's diverticulum

 

Explanation:

The presence of melena (dark tarry stools) suggests gastrointestinal bleeding.

The gastric mucosa in the ectopic location is a hallmark of Meckel's diverticulum.

Intermittent pain in the right iliac region can occur due to inflammation or obstruction.

Surgical exploration revealing a diverticular structure is characteristic of Meckel’s diverticulum.

Meckel's Diverticulum

Feature

Details

Definition

Congenital true diverticulum of the small intestine, resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.

Rule of 2’s

2% population, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2 inches in length, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric, pancreatic), 2 years most common presentation, 2:1 male predominance.

Clinical Features

Painless bleeding (melena), intestinal obstruction, diverticulitis, volvulus, intussusception.

Diagnosis

Meckel’s scan (Tc-99m pertechnetate scan for ectopic gastric mucosa).

Treatment

Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic.

 

Appendicular lump (Option B): incorrect because it typically presents with localized right lower quadrant pain, fever, and a mass due to inflammation, not melena or ectopic gastric mucosa.

 

Carcinoid (Option C): incorrect because carcinoid tumors present with flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing due to serotonin secretion, not intermittent pain and melena.

 

Obstructed bowel loops (Option D): incorrect because bowel obstruction typically presents with vomiting, distension, and absolute constipation, rather than melena and intermittent pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to disease progression?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Duration

 

Explanation:

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing skin cancer that rarely metastasizes.
  • Disease progression in BCC depends on:
    • Depth of invasion (deeper tumors are more aggressive).
    • Site (high-risk areas like the nose, periorbital region, and ears have a higher recurrence risk).
    • Stage of cancer (advanced stages indicate deeper tissue involvement).
  • Duration alone does not determine progression, as BCC can remain localized for years without significant spread.

Factors Affecting BCC Progression

Factor

Effect on Progression

Explanation

Depth

Yes

Deeper invasion into muscle, cartilage, or bone increases severity

Site

Yes

High-risk sites (face, scalp, ears) have more aggressive behavior

Stage of Cancer

Yes

Later stages indicate increased tumor burden and invasion

Duration

No

Slow growth means duration does not directly impact aggressiveness

Depth (Option B): Incorrect because deeper BCC lesions have worse prognosis.

Site (Option C): Incorrect because BCC at high-risk locations has higher recurrence and morbidity.

Stage of Cancer (Option D): Incorrect because advanced-stage BCC is more difficult to treat.

questions.text: Fetal anaemia is monitored by?
questions.solution:
Fetal anaemia is monitored by the middle cerebral artery-peak systolic volume assessment of the fetus during the antenatal period.

 

  • MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler ultrasound is a non-invasive method to assess fetal anaemia, which can occur due to Rh isoimmunization.
  • MCA PSV >1.5 MoM for the corresponding gestational age, predicts a moderate to severe degree of fetal anaemia.
  • Currently, MCA PSV is the mainstay of fetal surveillance in a case with red cell alloimmunization.
  • This value (between 24 and 35 weeks of gestation) is an indication of cordocentesis and intrauterine fetal transfusion


 

Algorithm of antenatal management of Rh Isoimmunisation:

questions.text: A patient was presented to the OPD with complaints of greenish black matter in the nose with merciful smelling. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Atrophic Rhinitis is a chronic nasal condition characterized by the atrophy of the nasal mucosa, turbinates, and underlying bones, leading to the formation of foul-smelling nasal crusts. The patient presents with greenish-black nasal crusts and a merciful (foul) smell, which is characteristic of ozena (a term for atrophic rhinitis with a fetid odor).

 

Primary Atrophic Rhinitis:

 

Aspect

Details

Causes
  • Heredity
  • Endocrine disturbance
  • Racial factors
  • Nutritional deficiency
  • Infective: Klebsiella ozaenae
  • Autoimmune

Clinical Features

And Examination findings
  • Primarily affects females, starts around puberty
  • Foul-smelling nasal discharge; patients are usually unaware of it themselves and have anosmia (merciful anosmia).
  • Paradoxical nasal obstruction despite enlarged nasal chambers.
  • Epistaxis from crust removal.
  • Pale nasal mucosa, atrophied turbinates, potential septal perforation, nasal vestibule dermatitis, saddle nose deformity.
  • Possible extension to pharynx and larynx leading to atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis.
  • Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion cause hearing impairment.


 

Other Options:

 

Allergic Rhinitis (Option A): Presents with watery rhinorrhea, sneezing, nasal congestion, and itching but not with foul-smelling crusts.

 

Rhinitis Caseosa (Option C): Characterized by caseous (cheese-like) nasal secretions, often seen in chronic fungal or bacterial infections, but not typically with greenish-black crusts.

 

Rhinitis Sicca (Option D): Involves dryness of the nasal mucosa due to environmental factors but lacks foul-smelling crust formation.

questions.text: Identify the lymphatic structure from the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a distinct lobulated structure with a darker outer cortex and a lighter inner medulla. This is characteristic of the thymus.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Parts of the Thymus:

  1. Cortex:
    • The outer, more densely packed region of the thymus.
    • Filled with immature T cells (thymocytes), undergoing differentiation and maturation as they move towards the medulla.
    • The cortex contains thymic nurse cells that support the maturing thymocytes.
    • T cells express surface markers (like TCR, CD3, CD4, and CD8) during maturation.
    • Macrophages are present to phagocytose apoptotic T cells, which fail to mature properly.
  2. Medulla:
    • The inner, less densely populated region.
    • Dominated by epithelial cells with pale-staining nuclei and large cytoplasm.
    • Contains Hassall's corpuscles, concentric structures made of keratinized epithelial cells, involved in T cell regulation.
    • Dendritic cells and macrophages in the medulla present self-antigens to maturing T cells, ensuring the elimination of self-reactive cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Histology of the Thymus:

  • Epithelial Framework: Throughout the thymus, epithelial cells provide a structural scaffold for lymphocyte development and produce hormones like thymopoietin, which regulate T cell maturation and proliferation.
  • It is divided into lobules by connective tissue septa.
  • A protective blood-thymus barrier prevents antigens from entering, safeguarding T cell maturation.

With age, the thymus undergoes involution, where lymphoid tissue is replaced by fat, but it continues to produce mature T cells.

 


 

Tonsil (Option A): Tonsils contain lymphoid follicles with germinal centers. The histology of tonsils features these follicles, unlike the thymus.

 

Lymph node (Option B):

Lymph nodes also have lymphoid follicles but have a more defined capsule, cortex, paracortex, and medulla.

Spleen (Option C):

The spleen has a characteristic red pulp (containing blood) and white pulp (containing lymphocytes)

questions.text: A TB patient with HIV begins ART and experiences deterioration in health after 2 months. What is the likely cause?

choices.text: Development of drug resistance to TB drugs
Drug-drug interactions between TB and ART medications
Development of drug resistance to ART

questions.solution:
Answer: C) Immunological changes in the body

 

Explanation:

The deterioration of health after starting ART in an HIV-TB co-infected patient is most likely due to Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), which is caused by immunological changes in response to ART.

  • Mechanism:
    • ART restores CD4+ T-cell function and improves the immune response.
    • This leads to a stronger inflammatory response against pre-existing TB infection, worsening symptoms.
    • IRIS typically occurs 2–12 weeks after ART initiation.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Worsening TB symptoms (fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms).
    • New inflammatory lesions (e.g., enlarging TB lymph nodes, worsening pleural effusions).
    • No evidence of drug resistance.
  • Management:
    • Continue both TB treatment and ART.
    • NSAIDs or corticosteroids may be used for severe cases.

 

  • HIV-positive individuals face an 8-fold increased risk of developing TB and are prone to more severe and potentially fatal extrapulmonary TB.
  • To manage co-infection, ATT is initiated first, followed by ART after 2 weeks to mitigate the risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), an exaggerated inflammatory response.
  • Rifampin, a potent CYP inducer in ATT, accelerates the metabolism of certain ART drugs like nevirapine (NNRTI), dolutegravir (integrase inhibitor), and protease inhibitors (e.g., Ritonavir, Indinavir, lopinavir), reducing their effectiveness. However, nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and efavirenz can be safely combined with Rifampin.
  • Rifabutin, a weaker enzyme inducer, is often used as an alternative to mitigate drug interactions in ART.
  • All HIV-positive TB patients should also receive cotrimoxazole preventive therapy to guard against Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

 

  • Development of drug resistance to TB drugs (Option A) is incorrect because TB drug resistance develops over months to years, whereas IRIS occurs within weeks of ART initiation.

 

  • Drug-drug interactions between TB and ART medications (Option B) is incorrect because although interactions (e.g., rifampicin reducing ART levels) are common, they usually lead to virologic failure, not an inflammatory worsening.

 

  • Development of drug resistance to ART (Option D) is incorrect because ART resistance presents with viral load rebound and worsening HIV, not a paradoxical inflammatory response.

questions.text: Which anti-epileptic drug is commonly associated with gum hypertrophy and dizziness as side effects?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Phenytoin

 

Explanation:

Phenytoin is a commonly used anti-epileptic drug (AED) that is well known for causing gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and dizziness as side effects.

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilising neuronal membranes and preventing seizures.

Adverse effects of Phenytoin include:

  1. Gum Hypertrophy: Overgrowth of gingival collagen fibres can cause significant dental and oral health issues.
  2. Hirsutism and Acne: Excessive hair growth and acne are common dermatological side effects.
  3. Coarsening of Facial Features: Long-term use can lead to noticeable changes in facial appearance.
  4. Hypersensitivity Reactions: These can manifest as rashes, discoid lupus erythematosus, lymphadenopathy, and neutropenia.
  5. Megaloblastic Anemia: Phenytoin can interfere with folate absorption, leading to anaemia.
  6. Osteomalacia: Bone softening or weakening can occur due to interference with vitamin D metabolism.
  7. Hyperglycemia: Inhibition of insulin release can result in elevated blood sugar levels.
  8. Toxicity: Symptoms of toxicity include diplopia, nystagmus, and ataxia.
  9. During Pregnancy: Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a risk, characterised by hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, harelip, and microcephaly.

 

Carbamazepine (Option A) is incorrect because while it causes dizziness and ataxia, it is not associated with gum hypertrophy.

 

Levetiracetam (Option C) is incorrect because it commonly causes irritability and mood changes, but not gum hypertrophy.

 

Topiramate (Option D) is incorrect because it is associated with cognitive slowing, weight loss, and nephrolithiasis, but not gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: A patient with penicillin allergy presents with fever, burning micturition, and hearing problems accompanied by dizziness. Which drug is the most appropriate for the management?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Ciprofloxacin

 

Explanation:

The patient presents with fever, burning micturition (suggestive of a urinary tract infection, UTI), and hearing problems with dizziness (suggestive of ototoxicity). Given the penicillin allergy, the most appropriate alternative is Ciprofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone), which is:

  • Effective against common UTI pathogens (E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas).
  • Safe in penicillin-allergic patients.
  • Less likely to exacerbate hearing loss compared to aminoglycosides.

 

Ciprofloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Bioavailability ~70%,Moderate half-life (~4-5 hours)
  • Widely distributed in tissues and body fluids
  • Renal excretion

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (DOC)
  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) (DOC)
  • Gastrointestinal infections (e.g., traveller's diarrhoea)
  • Bone and joint infections

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea).
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness).
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture.
  • Photosensitivity.

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children (due to potential for cartilage damage)
  • Myasthenia gravis (can exacerbate muscle weakness)

 

  • Azithromycin (Option A) is incorrect because macrolides are not first-line for UTIs, as they have poor urinary penetration and limited coverage against Gram-negative uropathogens.

 

  • Amikacin (Option B) is incorrect because although aminoglycosides are effective against UTIs, they are highly ototoxic and nephrotoxic, which is risky given the patient’s hearing problems and dizziness.

 

  • Ampicillin-Clavulanic Acid (Option D) is incorrect because the patient has a penicillin allergy, making this option unsuitable.

questions.text: Which among the following is pressure epiphysis
questions.solution:
Pressure epiphysis takes part in joint formation and transmits weight. The head of the humerus is a pressure epiphysis as it forms the shoulder joint and bears load during movements.

Types of Epiphysis:

  1. Pressure Epiphysis – Participates in joint formation and weight transmission (e.g., head of humerus, lower end of radius).
  2. Traction Epiphysis – Non-articular, does not transmit weight (e.g., greater/lesser trochanter of femur, greater/lesser tubercle of humerus, mastoid process).
  3. Atavistic Epiphysis – Once independent but fused for nutrition (e.g., coracoid process of scapula, os trigonum).
  4. Aberrant Epiphysis – Not always present (e.g., head of the first metacarpal, base of other metacarpals).

The other options (elbow joint, wrist joint, and sternum) are not classified as pressure epiphyses.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine gestational sac or features suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Her serum β-hCG is 1,200 IU/L, which is below the discriminatory zone. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C) Repeat β-hCG after 48 hours

Explanation:
In a hemodynamically stable patient, when β-hCG levels are below the discriminatory zone (<1,500–2,000 IU/L) and ultrasound findings are inconclusive, the next step is to repeat β-hCG testing after 48 hours to assess the trend.

  • A doubling β-hCG level suggests a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

  • A plateauing or declining β-hCG raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy or early pregnancy loss.

 

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Blood examination should be done as a routine for:
    • Haemoglobin
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Total white cell count and differential count
    • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • Estimation of β-hCG: The suspicious find­ings are:
    • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy
    • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy
  • Sonography (TVS): The diagnostic features are:
    • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test.
    • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas.
    • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign).
    • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.
  • Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog­raphy: TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period.
  • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
  • So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.
  • Laparoscopy offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions.
  • Dilatation and curettage: Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive.
  • Serum progesterone: A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy.
  • Laparotomy offers benefits when in doubt.

Laparoscopy (Option A) is reserved for cases with significant clinical suspicion of ectopic pregnancy or instability.

Methotrexate therapy (Option B) is initiated only after a confirmed diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.

Dilatation and curettage (Option D) is used when miscarriage is suspected and histological confirmation is needed.

questions.text: A male presents with a history of vestibular schwannoma and psammoma bodies in the brain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Meningiomas are common extra-axial tumors that arise from the meninges and are often characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies, which are concentrically laminated calcifications.
  • These tumors are typically slow-growing and can cause symptoms due to compression of adjacent brain structures.
  • The association of vestibular schwannoma with meningioma is seen in Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to multiple nervous system tumors, including bilateral vestibular schwannomas and meningiomas.


 

Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM (Option B): GBM is the most aggressive primary brain tumor, typically arising from astrocytes. It is characterized by pseudopalisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation, not psammoma bodies. Unlike meningioma, which is well-circumscribed and extra-axial, GBM is an infiltrative intra-axial tumor.

 

Pilocytic Astrocytoma (Option C): This is a low-grade astrocytoma, most commonly seen in children and often located in the cerebellum. It is histologically characterized by Rosenthal fibers, which are eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped inclusions, but it does not show psammoma bodies. Additionally, pilocytic astrocytomas are not associated with vestibular schwannomas.

 

Oligodendroglioma (Option D): These tumors arise from oligodendrocytes and are commonly associated with calcifications and a "fried egg" appearance of tumor cells due to perinuclear clearing. However, unlike meningiomas, they do not contain psammoma bodies. Oligodendrogliomas are also intra-axial tumors, meaning they arise from within the brain parenchyma, whereas meningiomas are extra-axial.

questions.text: The following image shows
questions.solution:
The given image suggests Craniorachischisis, an open neural tube defect.

Craniorachischisis is the most severe form of NTD, characterized by a continuous open defect extending from the skull to the spine. The condition is uniformly fatal.

 

It presents as a combination of:

  • Anencephaly: Absence of the brain and cranial vault, with exposed neural tissue lacking skin coverage.
  • Rachischisis: A contiguous bony defect of the cervical spine, with exposed neural tissue due to the absence of meninges.

 

Spina Bifida (Option C):

Types of Spina Bifida

Description

Spina Bifida Occulta

  • Spine is abnormal, but the spinal cord is unaffected.
  • Overlying skin is usually normal.
  • May have a small dimple, tuft of hair, or sinus over the skin indicating the defect.

Meningocele (Option B)
  • Protrusion of a sac of meninges through the vertebral defect.
  • Contains only clear fluid, no neural components.
  • Transillumination is positive.

Myelomeningocele (Option D)
  • Sac protrudes through the defect and contains neural components herniating from the spinal cord.

questions.text: Scientists administered norepinephrine to guinea pigs, resulting in an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and a decrease in heart rate. What mechanism explains this response?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Baroreceptor stimulation

 

Explanation:

The administration of norepinephrine (NE) causes:

  • ↑ Systolic and diastolic blood pressure (due to α₁-mediated vasoconstriction).
  • ↓ Heart rate (bradycardia) despite norepinephrine’s β₁-stimulatory effects.

This paradoxical bradycardia occurs due to the activation of the baroreceptor reflex in response to increased blood pressure.

Baroreceptor Reflex:

 

Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

 

  • Beta-1 receptor blockade (Option A) is incorrect because norepinephrine stimulates β₁ receptors, increasing contractility, but the reflex bradycardia is due to vagal activation, not β₁ blockade.

 

  • Alpha-1 receptor blockade (Option B) is incorrect because norepinephrine activates α₁ receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure. Blocking α₁ receptors would cause vasodilation and hypotension, the opposite of the observed effect.

 

  • Baroreceptor inhibition (Option D) is incorrect because if baroreceptors were inhibited, heart rate would increase (not decrease) due to unchecked sympathetic activation.

questions.text: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chancroid

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a person with a history of a long-term sexual relationship presenting with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender lymphadenopathy points towards a diagnosis of Chancroid, typically caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Haemophilus ducreyi:

  • Gram-negative coccobacillus
  • Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor
  • Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains
  • Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining.

  • Clinical features of chancroid:
    • Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base
    • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
    • Incubation period of 3-10 days
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical presentation
    • Gram stain of ulcer exudate
    • Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity)
    • PCR (most sensitive method)
    • Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Treatment:
    • Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR
    • Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR
    • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR
    • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days
    • Treatment of sexual partners is crucial

Gonorrhea (Option A) typically causes urethritis and discharge, not painful ulcers or lymphadenopathy.

Chlamydia (Option B) can cause urethritis or cervicitis, but ulcers are rare.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) (Option C) presents with painless ulcers and later, painful lymphadenopathy, unlike the painful ulcers seen in chancroid.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, dull tympanic membrane with lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck was seen. Which of the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms—unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, dull tympanic membrane, and posterior triangle lymphadenopathy—raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), especially considering the geographic location (Nagaland, Northeast India, where NPC is more prevalent due to genetic and environmental factors, including Epstein-Barr virus association). Radiotherapy is the primary treatment for NPC, as it is highly radiosensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Grommet insertion + Steroids (Option A): Used for chronic OME but does not treat the underlying malignancy.

 

Grommet insertion (Option B): Temporary relief but inappropriate for NPC.

 

Steroids alone (Option C): May reduce inflammation but will not address the tumor.

questions.text: A case of death of a married female within 3 years of marriage was reported. Inquest is done by?
questions.solution:
• As per Section 196 of the BNSS (Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023), a Magisterial Inquest is mandatory in specific cases, including the death of a married woman within 7 years of marriage under suspicious circumstances.
  • Since the case involves the death of a married female within 3 years of marriage, it falls under the purview of a Magistrate Inquest, ensuring a thorough investigation into any possible foul play (such as dowry death or homicide).

 

In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest.

 

1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS)

  • Most common type of inquest in India.
  • Conducted by a police officer, generally not below the rank of Head Constable.

 

2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS)

  • Conducted by an Executive Magistrate, or Judicial Magistrate.
  • It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including:
    • Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody or any custody authorized by the court
    • Deaths due to police firing
    • Deaths in jail
    • Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if,
      • Commits suicide
      • In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence
      • Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf
      • There is any doubt regarding the cause of death
    • Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death
    • Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request
  • Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation
  • An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate.
  • The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death.

 

Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests:

Feature

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

Conducted by

Police officer

Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate)

Involvement of witnesses

Requires signatures of panchas

Does not require witness signatures

Witness statements

Admissible in court

Not admissible in court

Can order arrest

No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses

Can issue arrest warrants

Exhumation

Cannot order exhumation

Can order exhumation of a body

Autopsy orders

Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately

Orders autopsy only when necessary

Forensic analysis

Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera

Can order chemical analysis

 

Judicial (Option A): While a Judicial Magistrate can conduct an inquest, the term "Judicial" alone is too broad and not specific to the context of this question.

 

Police (Option B): A Police Inquest is conducted in routine cases, but for the death of a married woman within 7 years of marriage, a Magistrate Inquest is mandatory.

 

Coroner (Option C): The coroner system does not exist in India. Instead, Magistrates perform the functions of a coroner.

  • As per Section 196 of the BNSS (Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023), a Magisterial Inquest is mandatory in specific cases, including the death of a married woman within 7 years of marriage under suspicious circumstances.
  • Since the case involves the death of a married female within 3 years of marriage, it falls under the purview of a Magistrate Inquest, ensuring a thorough investigation into any possible foul play (such as dowry death or homicide).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist following were the findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer (A)Rickets

  • Rickets is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.
  • The X-ray shows fraying, cupping, and splaying of the metaphysis, along with widened growth plates, which are hallmark signs.
  • Clinically, the child presents with bow legs (genu varum) due to weakened bone structure.
  • Management includes vitamin D and calcium supplementation with dietary improvements.

 

Radiological Changes:

  • Decreased Calcification: Leads to the thickening of the growth plate.
  • Fraying: Initial change is the loss of the normal zone of provisional calcification adjacent to the metaphysis, which appears as a blurring or frayed appearance of the metaphyseal margin.
  • Cupping: Edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface, particularly noticeable at the distal ends of the radius, ulna, and fibula.
  • Splaying: Cartilage hypertrophy leads to the widening of the growth plate resulting in the widening (splaying) of the metaphyseal ends.
  • Generalized reduction in bone density: Osteopenia
  • Widening of the Metaphysis

 

 

Scurvy (Option B):

 

  • X-ray findings include white line of Frankel (dense metaphyseal line), Wimberger's ring (peripheral epiphyseal calcification), and Pelkan spurs (metaphyseal beaks).
  • Clinically presents with bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing.

Option C: Hypophosphatemia (Vitamin D–resistant Rickets)

  • Can mimic rickets radiologically but is associated with low serum phosphate and normal/low calcium.
  • Typically presents with persistent rickets despite vitamin D therapy.
  • Not a more common cause than Vitamin D deficiency rickets in india

Option D: None

  • Incorrect, as the X-ray and clinical findings clearly indicate rickets.

questions.text: A patient with grade 4 hemorrhoids underwent surgery, identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Haemorrhoid band kit

 

Explanation:

  • Grade 4 hemorrhoids are permanently prolapsed and require surgical intervention.
  • Rubber band ligation (RBL) is commonly used for hemorrhoid treatment, especially for grade 2 and 3 hemorrhoids, but may be attempted for early grade 4 cases before surgery.
  • If the patient underwent surgery, the most likely instrument used would be a hemorrhoidectomy (stapler or excision-based) rather than a band kit. However, if ligation was performed prior to surgery, a haemorrhoid band kit could have been used.

Hemorrhoid Treatment Options

Grade of Hemorrhoids

Treatment Options

Grade 1 (No prolapse)

Lifestyle modification, fiber, sitz bath, topical agents

Grade 2 (Prolapse, spontaneous reduction)

Rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared coagulation

Grade 3 (Prolapse, manual reduction needed)

Rubber band ligation, surgical excision if persistent symptoms

Grade 4 (Irreducible prolapse)

Surgical options: Hemorrhoidectomy (excision or stapler), laser hemorrhoidoplasty

Haemorrhoid resection kit (Option A): incorrect because resection is not performed using a specific "kit"; rather, standard surgical instruments or a stapler are used.

Stapler kit (Option B): incorrect because stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH) is an option, but not typically described as a "band kit".

CO2 laser (Option D): incorrect because laser hemorrhoidoplasty is an alternative to excision but is not the standard method for grade 4 hemorrhoids.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Role of Zinc:

  • Essential co-enzyme in metal enzymes like alkaline phosphatase.
  • Important structural components of gene regulatory proteins.
  • Involved in regulation, including gene expression.

Symptoms of zinc deficiency:

  • Diarrhea.
  • Mood changes.
  • Anorexia.
  • Neurological disturbances.
  • Hypogonadism

 
  • Growth retardation.
  • Alopecia (hair loss).
  • Weight loss.
  • Recurrent infections.

Copper Deficiency (Option A) is incorrect because it typically presents with myeloneuropathy (similar to subacute combined degeneration), anaemia, and leukopenia, rather than the characteristic dermatitis of zinc deficiency.

 

Vitamin C Deficiency (Option C) is incorrect because it causes scurvy, which presents with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hairs, rather than the dermatological findings seen in zinc deficiency.

 

Vitamin D Deficiency (Option D) is incorrect because it leads to rickets in children (bowing of legs, bone pain) and osteomalacia in adults, which are skeletal manifestations rather than the skin findings seen in zinc deficiency.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) First-Degree AV Block

 

Explanation:

  • The ECG shows a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) but consistently conducts P waves to QRS complexes, indicating first-degree AV block.
  • There are no dropped beats, ruling out higher-degree blocks.

 

First Degree AV Block

Pathology
  • First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles.
  • The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers.

Etiology
  • Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients.
  • In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system.
  • Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases.
  • Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma.

Clinical Features
  • Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG.
  • In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain.

ECG Features
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG.
  • PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves.

Treatment
  • Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient.
  • Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease.
  • No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening.

 

Second-Degree AV Block (Option A):

  • This block features progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex, which is absent in this ECG as there are no dropped beats.


 

Third-Degree AV Block (Option C):

  • Here, there is complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes.
  • This is absent in the ECG since P waves are consistently followed by QRS complexes.

 

Bundle Branch Block (Option D):

  • This condition shows a wide QRS complex with characteristic morphology.
  • This feature is absent in the ECG, where the QRS complexes are normal in width and shape

questions.text: Which of the following is the population norm for an ASHA worker?
questions.solution:
As per the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) guidelines, one Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is appointed for every 1000 population in plain areas and up to 2500 in tribal/hilly/difficult areas.

 

700–1000 (Option A) is incorrect because the standard norm is at least 1000 population per ASHA, not below that.

1000–1500 (Option B) is incorrect because while 1000 is the lower limit, the upper limit can extend up to 2500 in certain areas.

2000–2500 (Option D) is incorrect because while ASHAs may cover up to 2500 people in difficult areas, the standard norm starts from 1000 population, making this range incomplete.

questions.text: A child diagnosed with von Willebrand disease requires an understanding of the role of von Willebrand factor (vWF). What does von Willebrand factor primarily combine with?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Glycoprotein Ib

Explanation:

  • Von Willebrand factor (vWF) primarily binds to Glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) on platelets, facilitating platelet adhesion to damaged endothelium via exposed subendothelial collagen.
  • vWF also carries and stabilizes Factor VIII, preventing its degradation.
  • Von Willebrand disease (vWD) results in defective platelet adhesion and prolonged bleeding time.

 

gp1b-IX is a membrane complex in platelets that facilitates binding to the von Willebrand Factor which is defective/deficient in von Willebrand disease.

 

 

 

Platelet factor 3 (Option B): PF3 is a phospholipid aiding coagulation but does not directly bind vWF.

ADP (Option C): ADP is involved in platelet aggregation, not adhesion.

 

Prothrombin (Option D): Prothrombin (Factor II) converts to thrombin but does not interact with vWF.

questions.text: A patient presents with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

  • Gum bleeding & petechiae: Classic signs of scurvy, caused by vitamin C deficiency, due to impaired collagen synthesis leading to fragile capillaries.
  • Poor wound healing: Vitamin C is crucial for collagen formation and connective tissue repair, and its deficiency results in defective wound healing.
  • Other symptoms of scurvy: Fatigue, corkscrew hairs, anemia, and subperiosteal hemorrhages.

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Feature

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Cause

Poor dietary intake (malnutrition, alcoholism, elderly, infants on cow's milk)

Key Symptoms

Bleeding gums, petechiae, bruising, corkscrew hairs, poor wound healing

Other Signs

Subperiosteal hemorrhage, joint pain, anemia, weakness

Diagnosis

Clinical features, low plasma vitamin C levels

Treatment

Vitamin C supplementation

Vitamin A Deficiency (Option A): Incorrect because it causes night blindness, dry skin, and keratomalacia, not bleeding gums or petechiae.

Vitamin B6 Deficiency (Option B): Incorrect because it presents with irritability, glossitis, peripheral neuropathy, and seizures, not connective tissue defects.

Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency (Option C): Incorrect because it causes pellagra (3 Ds- diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia) with photosensitive rash, not gum bleeding.

questions.text: A female presents with hirsutism, delayed periods, obesity. USG findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario—hirsutism, delayed periods (oligomenorrhea), and obesity—along with ultrasound findings (necklace pattern of peripheral cysts) strongly suggests Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS, also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous endocrine disorder in reproductive-age women characterized by metabolic and ovarian dysfunction.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

 

Clinical features of PCOS:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

 

Diagnostic criteria:

Modified Rotterdam Criteria: PCOS is diagnosed if any two of the following are present:

  1. Clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism
  2. Evidence of oligo-anovulation
  3. Polycystic appearing-ovarian morphology on ultrasound, with exclusion of other relevant disorders.
     
 

Feature

Recommended Diagnosis

1)

Biochemical Hyperandrogenism (or)

Elevated total or free testosterone, or calculated indices (FAI, BioT). DHEAS and ANSD can be considered.

Clinical Hyperandrogenism

Modified Ferriman–Gallwey score ≥4 to ≥8.

2)

Oligo-Anovulation

Oligo-amenorrhea (cycles >35 days apart or <8 menses/year).

3)

Polycystic Ovarian Morphology (On USG)

≥20 follicles per ovary (in either ovary) or ≥10 cm³ ovarian volume.

FAI—free androgen index, BioT—bioavailable testosterone, DHEAS—dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, ANSD—androstenedione.

 

USG: Necklace pattern ovarian cyst arranged towards the periphery.

Excessive stromal component in centre-producing androgens

 

Primary Ovarian Insufficiency (POI) or premature ovarian failure (Option B) occurs before 40 years and presents with amenorrhea, estrogen deficiency symptoms (hot flashes, vaginal dryness), and infertility. Hormonal evaluation shows elevated FSH (>40 mIU/mL) and low estrogen. Unlike PCOS, which has normal or low FSH with high androgens, POI is characterized by ovarian failure and lacks polycystic ovarian morphology on ultrasound.

 

Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) (Option C) is an acute complication of ovulation induction (hCG, gonadotropins), leading to fluid shifts, ascites, pleural effusion, and thrombosis risk. Patients develop rapid weight gain, abdominal distension, and massive ovarian enlargement (>10 cm) with multiple cysts. Unlike PCOS, which is a chronic condition, OHSS occurs post-fertility treatment and is associated with hemoconcentration and electrolyte imbalances.


Theca-Lutein Cysts (Option D) are benign, bilateral, multiloculated ovarian cysts caused by excess β-hCG stimulation in conditions like molar pregnancy, choriocarcinoma, and multiple gestations. Unlike PCOS, which is a chronic endocrine disorder, theca-lutein cysts are transient and regress once β-hCG normalizes.

questions.text: The ureter is safe in which type of hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Vaginal

Explanation:

  • In vaginal hysterectomy, the ureter is least at risk of injury because:
    • The procedure is performed entirely through the vaginal route without significant dissection near the ureter.
    • There is less manipulation of pelvic structures compared to other approaches.
  • Other methods like open, laparoscopic, and robotic hysterectomy involve greater ureteric handling, increasing the risk of thermal injury, ligation, or transection.

Ureteric Safety in Hysterectomy Types

Hysterectomy Type

Ureteric Injury Risk

Reasons

Open laparotomy

Moderate

Direct ureteric handling, risk during ligation

Laparoscopic

High

Increased risk due to thermal and traction injuries

Robotic

Moderate to high

Similar to laparoscopic but better visualization

Vaginal

Lowest

Minimal ureteric dissection, lower risk of injury

Open laparotomy (Option A): Incorrect because ureteric injury can occur during ligation of uterine vessels or parametrial dissection.

Laparoscopy (Option B): Incorrect as ureteric injury is common due to thermal damage from electrocautery.

Robotic (Option C): Incorrect since it has a similar risk as laparoscopic hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which findings are suggestive of tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium
Adnexal mass with empty uterus and fluid in pelvis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Adnexal mass with empty uterus and fluid in pelvis

Explanation:

 

Tubal (ectopic) pregnancy occurs when a fertilized ovum implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. The characteristic ultrasound findings suggestive of a tubal pregnancy include:

  1. Adnexal mass – Represents the ectopic pregnancy, often seen as a tubal ring or a gestational sac outside the uterus.
  2. Empty uterus – Absence of an intrauterine gestational sac despite a positive pregnancy test.
  3. Fluid in the pelvis – Suggests hemoperitoneum due to rupture or bleeding from the ectopic site.

 

Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium (Option A) suggests an ovarian pathology (e.g., corpus luteum cyst), not tubal pregnancy.

 

Adnexal mass with empty uterus (Option B): While this is suggestive, the presence of fluid in the pelvis increases suspicion of rupture.


Trilayer endometrium without adnexal mass (Option C): A trilaminar endometrium is seen in normal early pregnancy or luteal phase and does not indicate an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for the given image?
questions.solution:
Female genital tuberculosis (FGTB) primarily affects the fallopian tubes (M/c) and the endometrium. It can lead to tubal blockage, infertility, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian masses, and pelvic adhesions.

Diagnosis:

  • Definitive: AFB on microscopy/culture or epithelioid granulomas on histopathology (low sensitivity).
  • Imaging: Ultrasound, CT, MRI, and PET scan aid in diagnosis.
  • Molecular Tests: PCR (high sensitivity, high false positives), Gene Xpert (promising for extrapulmonary TB).
  • Laparoscopy (Gold Standard): Reveals caseous nodules, tubercles, adhesions, shaggy areas, straw-colored fluid.
  • Key Signs:
    • Sharma’s Python Sign: Alternating constriction and dilatation of fallopian tubes.
    • Sharma’s Kissing Fallopian Tubes Sign: Fusion and blockage due to caseous material and adhesions.

Image showing kissing fallopian tube sign. Nodules are also seen

 

Normal Fallopian Tube (Option B): The fallopian tube normally appears thin-walled, mobile, and patent with a uniform lumen. No tubal distortion, adhesions, or nodules are seen in normal tubes.

Hydrosalpinx (Option C): It refers to fluid-filled, dilated fallopian tubes due to chronic infection or tubal blockage. The tube appears distended, with a thin wall and no internal nodules. In contrast, genital TB causes thickened walls with caseous nodules and adhesions, as seen in the given image.

Endometriosis (Option D): It leads to chocolate cysts (ovarian endometrioma), dense adhesions, and powder-burn lesions on the peritoneum, uterus, and ovaries. Unlike TB, it does not show caseous nodules or tubal beading.

 

 

Image showing kissing ovaries sign

(sonographic sign of moderate to severe endometriosis)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found unconscious after a fall from a ladder. In the emergency department, his eyes do not open even in response to pain; he is making incomprehensible sounds, and he exhibits abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)6

 

Explanation:

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a tool used to assess a patient’s level of consciousness based on three parameters: eye-opening, verbal response, and motor response.

  • Each parameter is scored, and the total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
    • Eye response: The patient's eyes do not open, even in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 1.
    • Verbal response: The patient makes incomprehensible sounds, corresponding to a score of 2.
    • Motor response: The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing) in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 3.
  • Thus, the GCS score for this patient is: 1 (Eye) + 2 (Verbal) + 3 (Motor) = 6

Simplified Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) Table

Category

Response

Score

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

To speech

3

To pain

2

None

1

Verbal Response (V)

Oriented

5

Confused conversation

4

Inappropriate words

3

Incomprehensible sounds

2

None

1

Motor Response (M)

Obeys commands

6

Localizes to pain

5

Withdraws from pain

4

Abnormal flexion (decorticate)

3

Abnormal extension (decerebrate)

2

No response

1

 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification

Minor head injury

GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness)

Mild head injury

GCS 14 or 15 with LOC

Moderate head injury

GCS 9 - 13

Severe head injury

GCS 3 - 8

 

The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS.

 

Pupils Unreactive to Light

Pupil Reactivity Score

Both Pupils

2

One Pupil

1

Neither Pupil

0

 

  • GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15
  • GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury

questions.text: This instrument is contraindicated for?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a forceps used for assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Forceps delivery is contraindicated in obstructed labor because the fetus cannot be safely delivered vaginally due to cephalopelvic disproportion or other causes of obstruction. Applying forceps in such cases may lead to maternal and fetal complications like uterine rupture or birth trauma.


 

Instrument

Description

Piper forceps

  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births
  • It has distinct perineal curve, allows for application to the aftercoming head in breech delivery. (Option C)

Simpson forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

Wrigley's forceps

 
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

Kielland forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions. (Option D)
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

 

Caesarean section (Option A): Forceps can be used in cesarean deliveries to assist in delivering the fetal head, especially in cases of deep engagement or difficult extraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the classical triad of acute cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pain, jaundice, fever
 

Explanation:

Pain, jaundice, fever - this triad, known as Charcot's triad- indicates cholangitis.


 

Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Pain, jaundice, shock (Option B): This option is incorrect as shock is not part of Charcot's triad but is part of Reynolds's pentad.

 

Fever, jaundice, ↑WBC (Option C): ↑WBC, although it does occur in cholangitis, is not a component of Charcot's triad.


Pain, ↑WBC, ↑Bilirubin (Option D):↑Bilirubin, although it does occur in cholangitis, is not a component of Charcot's triad.

questions.text: When is a blood sample taken to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 72 hours after delivery

Explanation:

The blood sample taken for diagnosing neonatal hypothyroidism is 48-72 hours after delivery.

Diagnosis:

  • Primary hypothyroidism:
    • T4 level: low
    • TSH usually>100mIU/L
  • Central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels

X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis
  • Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae
  • X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures

Screening:

  • Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism
  • At birth, with umbilical cord blood (Option A)

Diagnostic:

  • Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72 hrs
  • Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge (vs Option B and C)
  • Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both

ASH's first strategy:

  • Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot
  • If TSH>20mIU/L, recheck
  • Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated.

Treatment:

  • Oral levothyroxine ( early morning with empty stomach for older children and for newborns; it is to be given at a fixed time)
  • The dose is higher in the earlier age group, and as the babies grow, the dose reduces.
  • Newborn- 10-15mg/kg/day
  • Children- 2-4mg/kg/day

questions.text: A child presents with telecanthus, hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, and cardiac defects. What is the most likely chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Microdeletion

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of telecanthus, hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, and cardiac defects is most consistent with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge syndrome or velocardiofacial syndrome).
  • This condition is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 22, specifically at the 22q11.2 region.

 

DiGeorge Syndrome:

 

Aspect

Details

Cause

Microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2.

Developmental Defect

Abnormal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches during embryogenesis.

 

Clinical Features:

 

Feature Type

Details

Facial Features
  • Hypertelorism (widely spaced eyes).
  • Antimongoloid slant of eyes.
  • Low-set ears.
  • Micrognathia (small jaw).
  • Short philtrum.
  • Bifid uvula.

Other Features
  • Hypocalcaemic tetany (due to hypoparathyroidism).
  • Aortic arch anomalies.
  • Thymic hypoplasia or aplasia.

 

Immunodeficiency:

 

T Cell Defect

Details

Prevalence

Present in 20–30% of patients.

Severity

Ranges from mild susceptibility to severe immunodeficiency requiring thymus or HSCT.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Molecular Genetic Testing: Detects the 22q11.2 microdeletion.

questions.text: In a patient with electric burns and stable vital signs, red-colored urine is observed. What is the most likely finding in the patient's serology?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations indicate Rhabdomyolysis secondary to electrical burns. When electrical current passes through muscle tissue, it causes extensive muscle damage, leading to the release of myoglobin, which gives urine its red color (myoglobinuria). The destroyed muscle cells release their contents, including potassium, creatine kinase, and myoglobin, into the circulation. Despite stable vital signs, hyperkalemia is a critical concern in these patients due to massive muscle cell destruction. Rhabdomyolysis is a type of false positive hematuria.

 

Causes of Abnormal Urine Colour:

Color

Pathologic Causes

Cloudy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Phosphaturia
  • Pyuria
  • Chyluria
  • Lipiduria
  • Hyperoxaluria

Cola coloured

Acute Glomerulonephritis

Brown
  • Bile pigments
  • Myoglobin

Brownish-black
  • Bile pigments
  • Melanin
  • Methemoglobin

Green or Blue
  • Pseudomonas UTI
  • Biliverdin

Orange

Bile pigments

Red
  • Hematuria
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Myoglobinuria (Rhabdomyolysis)
  • Porphyria
  • Beetroot ingestion

Yellow

Concentrated urine

Black

Alkaptonuria

 

RBCs in urine (Option A): Due to the given history of electrical burns, the more appropriate cause of red discolouration is due to myoglobinuria rather than hematuria. The presence of RBCs in urine would not be the primary finding in electrical burns.

 

Increased creatinine levels (Option B): Although creatinine levels may increase due to acute kidney injury secondary to myoglobinuria, this will not impart red discoloration of urine in electrical burns. The elevation in creatinine typically develops later as a consequence of kidney damage.


Decreased hemoglobin levels (Option C): Hemoglobin levels are not immediately affected by electrical burns unless there is significant blood loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture media used for tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is a selective egg-based culture medium used for isolating Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It contains malachite green, which inhibits contamination by other bacteria and promotes the growth of mycobacteria.


 

Enriched Media

Name

Characteristics

Image

Blood agar

Base medium enriched with 5-10% defibrinated sheep blood, used to grow moderately fastidious bacteria and observe hemolytic reactions.


 

Chocolate agar

This is an enriched medium made by heating blood agar, which lyses red blood cells and releases nutrients such as haemoglobin and NAD. It supports the growth of fastidious bacteria such as Haemophilus and Neisseria species.

Brain-heart infusion (BHI) broth

This is an enriched medium containing nutrients from brains and beef hearts, along with peptones, glucose, sodium chloride, and buffers. It supports the growth of non-fastidious and moderately fastidious microorganisms.

serum slope

An enriched medium with high serum content, prepared with eggs. Primarily used for the recovery and identification of Corynebacterium diphtheriae from nose and throat specimens.

Lowenstein-Jensen medium: Used specifically for cultivating Mycobacterium species, this enriched, selective medium contains glycerol, mineral salts, aspargine, malachite green, and hen’s eggs.

 

 

MacConkey medium (Option B) is incorrect because it is used for the isolation of gram-negative enteric bacteria, such as Escherichia coli and Salmonella, but not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Blood agar (Option C) is incorrect because it is a general-purpose medium used for cultivating fastidious bacteria like Streptococcus species, not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Chocolate agar (Option D) is incorrect because it is enriched with lysed red blood cells and used for growing Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria species, not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A woman, a few weeks after delivery, complains of bloody discharge from nipple and fever. On examination, diffuse lump under areola. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Lactational mastitis

 

Explanation:

  • Recent postpartum status → Lactating women are at high risk of mastitis due to milk stasis and bacterial infection.
  • Bloody nipple discharge and fever → Suggests infection and inflammation, which are characteristic of lactational mastitis.
  • Diffuse lump under the areola → Likely represents engorgement or inflammatory induration due to stasis or bacterial invasion (commonly Staphylococcus aureus).

Lactational Mastitis

Feature

Lactational Mastitis

Etiology

Bacterial infection due to milk stasis (commonly Staphylococcus aureus)

Risk Factors

Breastfeeding, nipple trauma (cracks), poor latch, prolonged engorgement

Symptoms

Fever, malaise, painful swollen breast, erythema, bloody or purulent discharge

Examination

Tender indurated mass, warmth, erythema over the affected breast

Complications

Breast abscess (if untreated)

Management

Frequent breastfeeding, warm compress, analgesics, antibiotics (dicloxacillin, cephalexin)

Galactocele (Option A): Incorrect because it presents as a painless cystic swelling due to milk retention, without fever, tenderness, or bloody discharge.

Mondor disease (Option C): Incorrect because it is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast, presenting as a palpable cord-like structure, not a diffuse lump or fever.

Fibrocystic disease (Option D): Incorrect because it causes cyclic breast pain and nodularity, typically worsening before menstruation, not postpartum infection.

questions.text: Which deficiency is most likely in a patient with delayed wound healing and alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Zinc

 

Explanation:

Zinc plays a crucial role in wound healing, protein synthesis, and maintenance of skin integrity, including hair follicle health. The combination of delayed wound healing and alopecia is particularly characteristic of zinc deficiency, as zinc is essential for both collagen synthesis and cell division necessary for tissue repair and hair growth.

 

Zinc

Function
  • Component of metalloenzymes
  • Involved in protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis
  • Necessary for steroid hormone receptors
  • Essential for spermatogenesis and fetal growth

Clinical Features of Zinc Deficiency
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Muscle wasting
  • Depression
  • Irritability
  • Rash
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Scaly dermatitis

Diagnostic Level of Zinc Deficiency

Serum zinc level <12 μmol/L (70 μg/dL)

 

  • Copper (Option B): While copper is important for collagen cross-linking and wound healing, it is not typically associated with alopecia as a primary manifestation. The primary features of copper deficiency include anemia and neutropenia. Copper deficiency more commonly presents with neurological symptoms and hematological abnormalities.

 

  • Calcium (Option C): Calcium deficiency primarily affects bone metabolism and neuromuscular function. It does not typically cause delayed wound healing or alopecia. The classic manifestations of calcium deficiency include tetany, muscle cramps, and bone abnormalities.

 

  • Vitamin D (Option D): Vitamin D deficiency primarily affects calcium homeostasis and bone metabolism. While it can have wide-ranging effects, delayed wound healing and alopecia are not characteristic features. The primary manifestations of vitamin D deficiency include bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures.

questions.text: Identify the level of lymph nodes indicated in the marked region of the neck in the given anatomical image.
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Level II

 

Explanation:

  • The marked lymph nodes are located along the upper part of the internal jugular vein, extending from the skull base to the hyoid bone.
  • Level II lymph nodes include the jugulodigastric nodes, commonly involved in head and neck malignancies.
  • They are subdivided into:
    • Level IIa: Medial to the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.
    • Level IIb: Posterior to the SCM muscle.

Cervical Lymph Node Levels

Level

Anatomical Location

Key Features

Level I

Submental & submandibular

Divided into Ia (midline) & Ib (lateral)

Level II

Upper internal jugular nodes

Jugulodigastric region (common in nasopharyngeal CA)

Level III

Mid-jugular region

Between the hyoid & cricoid

Level IV

Lower jugular nodes

Between the cricoid & clavicle

Level V

Posterior triangle

Spinal accessory nodes

Level Ia (Option B): Incorrect because these are submental nodes located in the midline under the chin.

Level Ib (Option C): Incorrect because these are submandibular nodes located between the mandible and submental region.

Level IV (Option D): Incorrect because these nodes are inferior to the cricoid cartilage, closer to the supraclavicular region.

questions.text: Identify the fracture:
questions.solution:
A depressed fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward due to high-impact trauma, commonly seen in blunt head injuries.



 

Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture

(Option D)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

 

Gutter fracture



 

Ring Fracture

 

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)

 

 
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

 

Ring fracture

 

 

Hinge fracture



 

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option B)

 

 

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.text: A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic. What is the gene associated with hand-feet syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HOXA13

Explanation:

Hand-Foot-Genital Syndrome (HFGS):

  • Rare, dominantly inherited condition affecting distal limbs and genitourinary tract.
  • Genetic cause:
    • Identified mutation in the HOXA13 homeobox gene.
    • HFGS is the second human syndrome linked to a HOX gene mutation.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Limb Malformations:
      • Bilateral shortening of thumbs and great toes, typically involving distal phalanx or first metacarpal/metatarsal.
      • Impaired dexterity or thumb apposition due to the malformations.
    • Urogenital Defects:
      • In females: Abnormalities in the ureters and urethra, incomplete müllerian fusion.
      • In males: Hypospadias with or without chordee.
      • Associated conditions: Vesicoureteral reflux, recurrent urinary tract infections, and chronic pyelonephritis.
      • Normal fertility.
  • Diagnosis and Testing:
    • Clinical Diagnosis:
      • Physical examination, radiographs of hands/feet, and imaging of kidneys, bladder, and female reproductive tract.
    • Genetic Diagnosis:
      • Identification of a heterozygous HOXA13 pathogenic variant confirms diagnosis if clinical/radiographic features are unclear.
  • Management:
    • Treatment of Manifestations:
      • Surgery for hand/foot malformations is usually unnecessary.
      • Ureteric reimplantation and bladder outlet abnormality correction often needed.
      • Rare surgical correction for vaginal septum or uterine abnormalities, unless recurrent pregnancy loss occurs.
    • Prevention of Secondary Complications:
      • Prophylactic antibiotics or surgery for urinary tract issues.
      • Gynecological exams before menstruation for hymenal constriction.
      • Pre-pregnancy evaluation for uterine and vaginal anatomy due to risks in pregnancy.

BCL6 gene (Option B) mutations are associated with B cell lymphomas and other cancers.

FGFR gene (Option C) mutation causes skeletal disorders, mainly dwarfism and craniofacial malformations.

COI 11 (Option D) mutation is associated with hearing loss.

questions.text: An elderly female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer is experiencing significant hair loss. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
