The most likely cause of significant hair loss in an elderly female undergoing chemotherapy is Anagen Effluvium. This type of hair loss occurs due to damage to the hair follicle during the anagen (growth) phase. It is commonly caused by chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or toxic agents that impair rapidly dividing cells, including hair follicle matrix cells. Hair loss is usually sudden, diffuse, and non-scarring, occurring within days to weeks after starting chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Telogen Effluvium (Option A): A temporary hair loss condition caused by stress, illness, or hormonal changes, leading to excessive shedding in the telogen (resting) phase. It is not a primary side effect of chemotherapy.

 

Trichotillomania (Option B): A psychiatric disorder characterized by compulsive hair pulling, leading to patchy hair loss with irregular borders. It is behavioral rather than treatment-induced.


Alopecia Areata (Option C): An autoimmune condition that causes sudden, patchy hair loss due to immune system attacks on hair follicles. It is unrelated to chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Prolyl hydroxylase

 

Explanation:

  • Role of Prolyl Hydroxylase and Vitamin C:
    • Prolyl hydroxylase catalyzes the hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen.
    • This process is essential for collagen stability via hydrogen bonding.
    • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, aiding in the regeneration of the enzyme’s Fe²⁺ active site.
  • Vitamin C Deficiency and Scurvy:
    • Deficiency leads to impaired collagen synthesis, causing fragile blood vessels, poor wound healing, and gingival bleeding (Scurvy).

Vitamin C-Dependent Enzymes in Collagen Synthesis

Enzyme

Function

Vitamin C Dependency

Prolyl hydroxylase

Hydroxylates proline residues in collagen for stability.

Yes

Lysyl hydroxylase

Hydroxylates lysine residues in collagen for cross-linking.

Yes

Lysyl oxidase

Cross-links collagen via aldehyde formation.

No (Requires copper)

Hydroxyprolyl kinase

Phosphorylates hydroxyproline.

No
  • Lysyl dehydrogenase (Option A): Incorrect because this enzyme is not involved in collagen synthesis and does not require Vitamin C.
  • Lysyl oxidase (Option B): Incorrect because it requires copper (Cu²⁺), not Vitamin C, for collagen cross-linking.
  • Hydroxyprolyl kinase (Option D): Incorrect because it phosphorylates hydroxyproline and is not dependent on Vitamin C.

questions.text: Which therapy is given for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Platinum-based chemotherapy, particularly Cisplatin or Carboplatin, is the first-line systemic treatment for advanced, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer. It is often used in combination with radiotherapy (concurrent chemoradiation) for locally advanced cervical cancer. Cisplatin enhances the effects of radiation and improves survival rates.

 

Management of cervical cancer

Stage

Management

Radiotherapy (Brachytherapy, Teletherapy)

Chemoradiation

IA1

Conization or extra fascial hysterectomy (if childbirth is completed)

Intracavitary brachytherapy alone (not surgical candidates).

NIL

IA2

Radical hysterectomy or radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

  

IB1

Radical hysterectomy or radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

NIL

Chemoradiation.

IB2

Radical hysterectomy

IB3

Chemoradiation

IIA1

Radical hysterectomy or chemoradiation.

IIA2

Chemoradiation

IIB-IVA

Chemoradiation and pelvic exenteration for central recurrences after radiotherapy.

External beam radiation therapy (40 to 50 Gy) for 5 weeks.

Brachytherapy (post ext. Beam radiation.

Concurrent chemotherapy, with cisplatin. (Option D)

IVB

Palliative; pelvic radiation to manage symptoms.

Pelvic radiation (symptom control)

Systemic chemotherapy


Options A, B, and C are incorrect as these are not the preferred treatment methods for cervical cancer

questions.text: A person got stabbed in his anterior thigh and died. His body was brought for postmortem. What type of injury is this?
questions.solution:
A penetrating wound is caused by a sharp object (e.g., a knife) that pierces the skin and enters deeper tissues or body cavities. In this case, the stab wound to the anterior thigh involves a sharp object penetrating the skin and underlying tissues, making it a penetrating wound.


 

Stab wound/Punctured wound

These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width.

Weapons used

  • Knife (most common)
  • Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle)
  • Scissors
  • Screwdrivers
  • Pens
  • Ice picks
  • Forks

Types of stab wounds

  • Puncture wound: (Option C)
    • Soft tissues are involved
  • Penetrating wound:
    • Enters a body cavity or a viscus
  • Perforating wound:
    • Through-and-through puncture wounds
    • The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other
    • The wound of entry is larger than the exit

Significance of the wound dimensions

  • Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin.
  • Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping.
  • Depth, the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation.
  • Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising.
    • Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges
    • If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed

Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is a clean cut caused by a sharp object (e.g., a razor or knife) and is typically longer than it is deep. A stab wound is deeper than it is long, so it does not qualify as an incised wound.

 

Blunt force injury (Option D): This involves trauma caused by a blunt object (e.g., a bat or hammer) and does not involve penetration of the skin or tissues. A stab wound is caused by a sharp object, not blunt force.

questions.text: Which of the following is the National Deworming Day?
questions.solution:
National Deworming Day (NDD) in India is observed on 10th February every year, with a mop-up round on 15th February. It is a public health initiative by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to eliminate Soil-Transmitted Helminths (STH) infections among children and adolescents aged 1–19 years.

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat: Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation)

  • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar-coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Feb and 10 of Aug of every year)
  • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole.

Menstrual hygiene management:

  • Sanitary pads are provided to girls
  • Usually in rural areas

10th August (Option B) is incorrect because this is not a recognised National Deworming Day. However, the biannual round in some high-risk areas may fall in August.

10th March (Option C) is incorrect because March is not the official NDD.

11th January (Option D) is incorrect as NDD is not observed on this date.

questions.text: Following a fight between 2 groups, a boy was brought with severe pain in the chest, distended neck veins, dyspnea, and a BP of 80/50 mmHg. X-ray shows the following findings: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Tension Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

  1. Clinical Presentation:
    • Severe chest pain, dyspnea, distended neck veins (JVD), and hypotension (80/50 mmHg) suggest a life-threatening tension pneumothorax.
    • Trauma history (fight) further supports the diagnosis.
  2. Increased Intrathoracic Pressure → Impaired Venous Return → Distended Neck Veins (JVD)
    • As intrathoracic pressure rises, it compresses the superior vena cava (SVC) and right atrium, obstructing venous return to the heart.
    • This results in jugular venous distension (JVD) due to backed-up blood in the venous system.
  3. Decreased Preload & Cardiac Output → Hypotension (Low BP)
    • The compression of the right atrium and ventricle reduces blood filling (preload), decreasing stroke volume and cardiac output.
    • This leads to severe hypotension and, if untreated, cardiac arrest due to obstructive shock.
  4. X-ray Findings:
    • Hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) on the right side due to air accumulation.
    • Mediastinal shift to the left due to increased intrathoracic pressure.
    • Depressed diaphragm on the affected side.
    • Absence of lung markings on the affected side.
  5. Management:
    • Immediate needle decompression at the 2nd intercostal space (midclavicular line) followed by chest tube placement.

Pneumothorax Types and Features

Type

Cause

Clinical Features

X-ray Findings

Tension Pneumothorax

Trauma, mechanical ventilation

Severe dyspnea, hypotension, JVD, tracheal deviation

Mediastinal shift away from affected side, hyperlucency

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Ruptured subpleural blebs (tall, thin males)

Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain

Hyperlucency without mediastinal shift

Traumatic Pneumothorax

Blunt/penetrating trauma, rib fractures

Dyspnea, pain, absent breath sounds

Hyperlucency, no mediastinal shift unless tension develops

Bilateral Pneumothorax

Rare, seen in severe trauma, barotrauma

Respiratory distress, hypoxia

Bilateral hyperlucency

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (Option B): incorrect because it occurs without trauma and does not cause severe hypotension or mediastinal shift.

Traumatic Pneumothorax (Option C): incorrect because not all traumatic pneumothoraces lead to tension, and tension features (JVD, severe hypotension, tracheal shift) are key here.

Bilateral Pneumothorax (Option D): incorrect because the X-ray shows a unilateral pneumothorax, not bilateral lung collapse.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is typically elevated in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Acid phosphatase

 

Explanation:

Acid phosphatase, specifically prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP), is an enzyme that is elevated in prostate cancer, particularly in advanced or metastatic cases. PAP was historically used as a tumour marker for prostate cancer, though prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is now the preferred marker.

  • Significance:
    • Elevated in prostate cancer with bone metastases
    • Can be used to monitor disease progression
    • Less commonly used now due to the superior sensitivity of PSA

 

  • Alkaline Phosphatase (Option B) is incorrect because while alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is elevated in bone metastases, it is not specific for prostate cancer and can also be seen in liver disease and bone disorders.

 

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (Option C) is incorrect because LDH is a non-specific marker of cell turnover and is elevated in various malignancies, not just prostate cancer.

 

  • Alpha-Fetoprotein (Option D) is incorrect because AFP is primarily a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumours, not prostate cancer.

questions.text: A patient presents with lower symmetric flaccidity and no cord reflex, suggesting which condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations indicate Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. This autoimmune condition typically presents with symmetric ascending paralysis and areflexia. The hallmark features include progressive muscle weakness that begins in the lower extremities and ascends upward, accompanied by diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes, which explains the patient's presentation of lower symmetric flaccidity and absent cord reflex.

 

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS)

Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

 

Multiple sclerosis (Option B): Multiple sclerosis typically presents with asymmetric symptoms and upper motor neuron signs, including hyperreflexia and spasticity, rather than the symmetric flaccid paralysis seen in this case.

 

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option C): ALS characteristically presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, including hyperreflexia, spasticity, and fasciculations, rather than pure flaccid paralysis with areflexia. The presence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs in the same body region is a hallmark of ALS.


Spinal cord injury (Option D): Spinal cord injury typically presents with a distinct sensory level and upper motor neuron signs below the level of injury, including hyperreflexia and spasticity, not the symmetric flaccid paralysis described. The injury pattern is usually asymmetric and depends on the mechanism and level of injury.

questions.text: A total of 2000 patients were assessed for HIV. 200 were diagnosed positive. A new ELISA screening test was tested on the same group. It showed 260 as positive out of which only 130 had the disease. What is the specificity of the test?
questions.solution:
Specificity is calculated using the formula:

 

Specificity = True Negatives (TN) / [True Negatives (TN) + False Positives (FP)] x 100

 

Step 1: Identify the given values

  • Total tested = 2000
  • Actual HIV-positive cases (True Positives + False Negatives) = 200
  • Total test-positive cases (True Positives + False Positives) = 260
  • True Positives (TP) = 130
  • False Positives (FP) = Total test positives - True Positives 260−130=130
  • True Negatives (TN) = Total actual negatives - False Positives (2000−200)−130 = 1800−130 = 1670

Step 2: Calculate Specificity

 

Specificity = [1670 / (1670 + 130)] x 100 = 92.78%

 

Rounding to the nearest whole number, specificity = 96%.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

Explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), is the most common cause of prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

  • It occurs following cardiac valve replacement.
  • Early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs within 12 months of valve replacement):
    • Generally nosocomial.
    • Results from intra-operative contamination of the prosthesis or a bacteremic postoperative complication.
    • Common agents: CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis) and S. aureus.
  • Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs after 12 months of valve replacement):
    • Usually community-acquired.
    • Common agents: Viridans streptococci.
  • Overall:
    • Regardless of the time of onset after surgery, CoNS are the most common agents (at least 68-85%).
    • Majority are methicillin-resistant CoNS.

Streptococcus viridans (Option A) is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, particularly following dental procedures or in patients with pre-existing valvular disease. However, it is not the primary cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), where Staphylococcal species predominate.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C) is a virulent pathogen that causes rapidly progressive (acute) infective endocarditis, affecting both native and prosthetic valves. It is a leading cause of healthcare-associated IE, often seen in intravenous drug users (IVDU) and patients with catheters or implanted devices. While it can cause prosthetic valve IE, it is more common in late-onset cases rather than early PVE.

Enterococci (Option D) (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis) are opportunistic pathogens that cause subacute endocarditis, particularly in elderly patients with genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections. Though they can infect prosthetic valves, they are not the primary causative agent.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting a large quantity of paracetamol tablets. What is the most likely progression of paracetamol poisoning in this case?

choices.text: Increase in liver enzymes within 24 hours
Paracetamol achieves peak concentration within 4 hours

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Increase in liver enzymes within 24 hours

 

Explanation:

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning follows a predictable progression based on the time since ingestion. The first 24 hours are usually asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms, but a rise in liver enzymes (AST, ALT) occurs as hepatotoxicity begins.

 

Metabolism of Acetaminophen
  • Acetaminophen is mainly metabolized via phase II reactions into harmless sulfate and glucuronide metabolites.
  • A small portion undergoes phase I metabolism by CYP2E1, forming the hepatotoxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI).

Detoxification of NAPQI

  • NAPQI is neutralized by binding to glutathione, forming water-soluble mercapturic acid, which is excreted via the kidneys.

Glutathione Depletion

  • When excessive NAPQI is produced, or glutathione is depleted, NAPQI binds to hepatocyte macromolecules, forming acetaminophen-protein adducts, causing hepatocyte necrosis.

Risk Factors
  • Chronic alcohol use (induces CYP2E1, depletes glutathione).
  • Starvation.
  • Prior use of mixed-function oxidase-inducing drugs (e.g., phenobarbital, INH).
  • Hepatitis C infection increases the risk of liver injury in overdose.

Clinical features

Early Symptoms (4-12 hrs):

  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, shock.

Delayed Symptoms (24-48 hrs):

  • Hepatic injury becomes apparent.
  • Coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
  • Maximal damage seen 3–5 days post-ingestion with aminotransferase levels >10,000 IU/L.
  • Renal failure and myocardial injury may occur.

 

Stages of acute acetaminophen poisoning

Stage

Time Post-Ingestion

Description

I

0–24 hours

Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

II

24–72 hours

Right upper quadrant abdominal pain; elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), and sometimes increased bilirubin and INR if poisoning is severe.

III

72–96 hours

Vomiting, signs of liver failure; peak levels of AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR. Possible renal failure and pancreatitis.

IV

> 5 days

Recovery of liver function or progression to multiple organ failure.

 

  • Liver failure within 24 hours (Option B) is incorrect because severe liver failure typically occurs at 72–96 hours, not within the first 24 hours.

 

  • Paracetamol achieves peak concentration within 4 hours (Option C) is incorrect because while paracetamol reaches peak plasma levels in 30 minutes to 2 hours, this does not define the course of toxicity.

 

  • Recovery within 72 hours (Option D) is incorrect because severe toxicity peaks at 72–96 hours, with either recovery or progression to liver failure afterward.

questions.text: Which of the following are the changes seen in irreversible cell injury
questions.solution:
Irreversible cell injury is characterized by severe damage to cellular structures, leading to cell death via necrosis or apoptosis. The hallmark of irreversible cell injury is damage to mitochondria, specifically the appearance of amorphous densities within mitochondrial matrices, which indicates a point of no return in cell injury. This suggests permanent mitochondrial dysfunction, loss of ATP production, and cell death.


 

(Option A): This is an early and reversible change in cell injury, where the plasma membrane forms protrusions due to cytoskeletal disruption.

 

(Option C): This occurs due to decreased ATP and ionic imbalances but is still reversible unless nuclear fragmentation (karyorrhexis or karyolysis) occurs.

 

(Option D): This is also a reversible change caused by failure of ion pumps, leading to intracellular water accumulation.

questions.text: A neonate presents with a growing skin lesion, as shown in the image provided. The mother reports that the lesion has been increasing in size daily. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate Biopsy due to Malignancy Risk

questions.solution:
Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that commonly appear within the first few weeks of life. They typically grow rapidly during the first few months (proliferative phase) before undergoing spontaneous involution over several years.

Most do not require intervention unless they cause complications such as airway obstruction, ulceration, or vision impairment.

 

Other options:

 

Excision and Laser Therapy (Option B): Reserved for complicated hemangiomas (e.g., ulcerated, functionally impairing, or rapidly growing in critical areas like the airway or eyes).

 

Immediate Biopsy due to Malignancy Risk (Option C): Unnecessary, as infantile hemangiomas are benign and diagnosed clinically.

 

Cryotherapy (Option D): Not an appropriate treatment for hemangiomas, as they typically regress without intervention.

questions.text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation.
Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.
Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Diagnosis

Gestational Diabetes

Pre-existing Diabetes

Timing

During pregnancy

Present before conception

Criteria

Fasting Plasma glucose

92 mg/dL

126 mg/dL (on two occasions)

1-hour plasma glucose

180 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms)

2-hour plasma glucose

153 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals)

HbA1c

≥5.7-6.4%

≥6.5%

Management

Resolves after delivery.

Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy.

 

  • After experiencing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) during pregnancy, a mother may have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes in later life.
  • Lifestyle modifications are appropriate, but immediate diagnosis and management of GDM are necessary.
  • Monitoring without intervention is inappropriate because the patient meets the criteria for GDM diagnosis and requires management to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A patient shows flat affect. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Flat affect refers to a lack of emotional expression, where the patient shows little or no facial expressions, gestures, or vocal tone variations despite the context. This is classified as a negative symptom in psychiatric disorders, especially schizophrenia. Negative symptoms represent a loss or reduction of normal functions, such as diminished emotional expression, social withdrawal, and lack of motivation.

 

Types:

  1. Positive Symptoms (Option A): These reflect exaggerations or distortions of normal functions.
  • Delusions: False beliefs not based in reality, e.g., persecutory or grandiose delusions.
  • Hallucinations: Perceptions without external stimuli, typically auditory (e.g., hearing voices).
  • Disorganised speech: Incoherent or illogical speech, such as loose associations or "word salad."
  • Disorganised behaviour: Erratic or inappropriate actions, including agitation or inappropriate affect.

​​​​​​​2. Negative Symptoms: These involve loss or reduction of normal functions.

  • Avolition: Lack of motivation to perform goal-directed activities, such as self-care.
  • Anhedonia: Inability to experience pleasure from activities which were previously preasurable.
  • Alogia: Poverty of speech, brief or uninformative responses.
  • Flat affect or Blunting actions (Option B): Reduced emotional expression, monotone speech, or lack of facial expressions.
  • Social withdrawal: Lack of interest in social relationships.

3.Cognitive Symptoms (Option D): These affect thinking and memory and have a moderate prognosis.

  • Impaired attention: Difficulty focusing or sustaining attention.
  • Impaired working memory: Trouble holding and manipulating information.
  • Executive dysfunction: Difficulty with planning, organising, and problem-solving.
  • Slowed processing speed: Slower response to information and tasks.


 

Other Options:


Affect symptom (Option C): While flat affect is related to emotional expression, "affect symptom" is not a standard classification in psychiatric terminology. Instead, it falls under negative symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the use of Shakir's tape?
questions.solution:
Shakir's tape (Mid-Upper Arm Circumference or MUAC tape) is a simple, low-cost, and effective tool used to assess malnutrition in children. It is an example of appropriate technology, which refers to cost-effective, easily accessible, and locally adaptable healthcare solutions.

 

Shakir’s tape:

 

  • MUAC tapes measure the upper arm circumference of children and pregnant women to identify malnutrition.
  • There are different types of MUAC tapes, all graduated in millimetres.
  • Some tapes are colour-coded (red, yellow, green) to indicate nutritional status.
  • MUAC tapes are used to assess nutritional status quickly and non-invasively, aiding in timely intervention for malnutrition.
  • MUAC tapes for children and adults are available through UNICEF Supply Division warehouses.
  • It cannot be used for infants.
  • Interpretation:

 

Red

<11.5 cm

Severe Malnutrition

Yellow

11.5-12.5 cm

Borderline Malnutrition

Green

>12.5 cm

Normal

 

Intersectoral coordination (Option A) is incorrect because intersectoral coordination involves collaboration between different sectors (health, education, agriculture, etc.), whereas Shakir's tape is a specific nutritional assessment tool.

Equitable distribution (Option B) is incorrect because equitable distribution refers to fair allocation of healthcare resources, not the use of a diagnostic tool.

Community participation (Option D) is incorrect because while Shakir's tape is used at the community level, community participation refers to involvement of local populations in health initiatives, rather than just using a tool for assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Hyaluronic Acid

 

Explanation:

  • Natowicz Disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type IX - MPS IX)

    • Definition: A rare autosomal recessive mucopolysaccharidosis caused by hyaluronidase deficiency.

    • Biochemical Defect:

      • Hyaluronidase is responsible for degrading hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan).

      • Deficiency leads to accumulation of hyaluronic acid.

    • Glycosaminoglycan Involved:

      • Hyaluronic acid (a non-sulfated GAG).

    • Clinical Features:

      • Mild phenotype compared to other MPS types.

      • Soft tissue masses (especially periarticular), joint stiffness.

      • Normal intelligence and no significant skeletal or neurological abnormalities.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) & Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) Accumulation

Heparan N-sulfatase, etc.

(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the procedure?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)

 

Explanation:

  • VP is a radiographic study of the urinary tract using intravenous contrast.
  • The contrast is injected intravenously, filtered by the kidneys, and visualizes the renal calyces, pelvis, ureters, and bladder in sequential X-ray images.
  • The characteristic findings in IVP include contrast-filled renal collecting systems, ureters, and bladder, differentiating it from other contrast-based urinary tract studies.

Urinary Tract Imaging Techniques

Procedure

Method

Indications

Key Features

Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)

IV contrast injection

Suspected urinary obstruction, nephrolithiasis, tumors

Contrast seen in kidneys, ureters, and bladder on sequential films

Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP) (Option A ruled out)

Contrast injected via cystoscopy into ureters

Suspected ureteral obstruction, non-visualization on IVP

Contrast opacifies the ureter and renal pelvis without nephrogram

Antegrade Pyelography (Option D ruled out)

Contrast injected percutaneously into the renal pelvis

Upper urinary tract obstruction, post-surgical assessment

Contrast fills renal pelvis and ureters from above

Combined RGP & Ureteroscopy (Option B ruled out)

Ureteroscope inserted via cystoscopy + contrast study

Ureteric stones, strictures, or tumors

Direct visualization of ureter along with contrast study

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Right Hepatic Artery

 

Explanation:

  • Course and Branching:
    • The Right Hepatic Artery (RHA) originates from the Proper Hepatic Artery and courses toward the right lobe of the liver.
    • It runs behind the common hepatic duct and gives rise to the Cystic Artery, which supplies the gallbladder.
  • Image-Based Identification:
    • The marked structure is seen branching toward the right lobe of the liver, which aligns with the usual anatomical location of the Right Hepatic Artery.
    • Its size and direction distinguish it from smaller branches such as the Cystic Artery.

Right Hepatic Artery

Feature

Description

Origin

Proper Hepatic Artery (branch of Common Hepatic Artery)

Course

Runs behind the common hepatic duct and ascends toward the right lobe of the liver

Branches

Cystic artery (to gallbladder), Segmental branches to liver

Function

Supplies the right lobe of the liver and gallbladder

Clinical Importance

Injury during cholecystectomy can lead to hemorrhage or hepatic ischemia

Cystic Artery (Option A): Incorrect because the cystic artery is a smaller branch of the RHA that supplies the gallbladder, whereas the marked structure is larger and directed toward the liver.

Hepatic Duct (Option C): Incorrect because the hepatic duct is a biliary structure that transports bile, not an artery.

Cystic Duct (Option D): Incorrect because the cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the bile duct system and does not match the marked arterial structure.

questions.text: A firefighter was admitted with fever, cough, culture shown in the image reveals gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Explanation: The firefighter with fever and cough has a culture showing gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli with fluorescent colonies under UV light, which is characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Diagnostic Tests for Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

Diagnostic Method

Description

Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Sample Collection

Collect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Specimens vary based on the site of infection.

Microscopy

Gram stain

Gram-negative rods; motile with flagella.

Culture

Growth on common laboratory media:

Blood agar

Produces beta-hemolytic gray, moist colonies.

MacConkey agar

Produces pale, non-lactose fermenting colonies, Fluorescence under UV light.

Nutrient agar

Produces large, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen.

Peptone water

Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle.

Cetrimide Agar

Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin).
 

King’s medium

used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas

Biochemical Tests

Various biochemical tests to identify specific metabolic properties:

Oxidase test

Positive

Catalase test

Positive

ICUT Test:

Indole test

Negative

Citrate test

Positive

Urease test

Negative

Triple sugar test

Shows alkaline slant with no gas and hydrogen sulfide.

Molecular Methods

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencing

Provides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA.

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing

Disk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testing

Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics.

Klebsiella (Option A): Although Gram-negative, it is oxidase-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and typically forms mucoid colonies due to its capsule.
Staphylococcus aureus (Option B) is Gram-positive, whereas the given organism is Gram-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and forms golden-yellow colonies, not greenish ones.
Serratia (Option D) is Gram-negative and oxidase-negative. Some Serratia species produce red pigment (prodigiosin), but they do not fluoresce under UV light like Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: Histopathological examination showed follicular cells with pink eosinophilic cytoplasm. It is seen in?
questions.solution:
Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized histologically by follicular cells with abundant pink, eosinophilic cytoplasm. This eosinophilic change is due to the presence of Hurthle cells (oncocytic cells), which are large follicular cells with abundant mitochondria. Hurthle cell changes can also be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, a variant of follicular carcinoma.


 

Papillary CA (Option A): Characterized by papillary structures, Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies. Does not prominently feature eosinophilic cytoplasm in follicular cells.

Medullary CA (Option C): Derived from parafollicular C cells and secretes calcitonin. Histologically shows amyloid deposits (Congo red positive) and polygonal cells in nests.

Anaplastic CA (Option D): Highly aggressive and undifferentiated. Composed of pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and high mitotic activity, with no follicular architecture or Hurthle cell features.

questions.text: The toughness of bacterial cell walls is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peptidoglycan

Explanation: Toughness of bacterial cell wall is due to Peptidoglycan.

Bacterial Cell Wall:

  • Tough and rigid structure surrounding the bacterium.
  • 10-25 nm in thickness and constitutes 20-25% of the dry weight of the cell.
  • Functions of Cell Wall:
    • Provides protection to the cell against osmotic lysis.
    • Confers rigidity upon bacteria due to the presence of a peptidoglycan layer in the cell wall.
    • Protect a cell from toxic substances and is the site of action of several antibiotics.
    • Contains certain virulence factors (e.g., endotoxin), which contribute to bacterial pathogenicity.
    • Antibody raised against specific cell wall antigens (e.g., antibody to LPS) may provide immunity against some bacterial infections.

Difference between Gram-positive and Gram-negative Bacterial Cell Walls:

Gram-positive

Features

Gram-negative

Thick layer

Peptidoglycan layer

Thin layer

100 layer thick

Thickness

1–2-layer thickness

2-5 %

Lipid content

15-50%
  • Peptidoglycans+++
  • Lipoproteins
  • Teichoic acid

Composition
  • Lipopolysaccharide
  • Lipoproteins
  • Peptidoglycan+

Absent

Outer membrane

Present

Absent

Periplasmic space + Porins

Present

Present

Teichoic acid (used for

attachment)

Absent

Present

Pentapeptide cross bridge

Absent

Present

NAM-NAG

Present

Teichoic acid (Option A) is present in Gram-positive bacteria, but it mainly contributes to cell wall stability and ion transport, not toughness.

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) (Option C) are found in Gram-negative bacteria, but they form the outer membrane, playing a role in immune evasion and permeability, not rigidity.

The outer membrane (Option D) is present in Gram-negative bacteria, providing selective permeability and protection, but the structural strength comes from peptidoglycan.

questions.text: Leading questions can be asked in?
questions.solution:
• A leading question suggests the answer within the question itself, often prompting a "yes" or "no" response.
  • These questions are typically allowed during cross-examination but not during examination-in-chief or re-examination, except in special circumstances.

 

Examination of Witness:

The below sequence is based on the Sec. 138 IEA.

Oath

↓

Chief examination

↓

Cross-examination

↓

Re-examination

 

Aspect

Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination)

Cross-Examination

Re-Examination

Conducted By

Party who calls the witness (e.g., public prosecutor)

Opposing party (typically defense)

Party who called the witness

Purpose
  • Present all relevant facts
  • Provide expert interpretation if applicable
  • Challenge witness's credibility
  • Elicit favorable facts
  • Test accuracy

Clarify issues raised during cross-examination

Leading Questions

Not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile (Option D)

Allowed (Sec. 146 BSA)

Not allowed (Option B)

Nature of Questions

Open-ended questions to elicit narrative

Can include leading questions to control the narrative

Generally clarifying questions

Time Limit

Typically structured and may have time constraints

No set time limit; may last for hours or even days

Generally limited to clarification purposes

Judicial Oversight

Judge may intervene to ensure questions are relevant and not leading

Court can disallow indecent or scandalous questions (Sec. 154, BSA)

Judge monitors to ensure focus remains on clarification

 

Anytime (Option C): This is incorrect because leading questions are restricted during examination-in-chief and re-examination.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation?
questions.solution:
Olanzapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is commonly associated with significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. Many patients discontinue the medication due to excessive weight gain, increased appetite, and risk of metabolic syndrome (including diabetes and dyslipidemia). This is one of the most frequent reasons for non-compliance with olanzapine treatment.

 

  • Antipsychotic Medications:

 

First Generation Antipsychotics

(Typical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

D2 receptor antagonist

Partial D2 Agonists

D2/5-HT2A Antagonists
  • Haloperidol
  • Fluphenazine
  • Perphenazine
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Brexpiprazole
  • Cariprazine
  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone
  • Lurasidone
  • Clozapine
  • Treatment Duration:
    • For first-episode patients, a minimum of 1-2 years of treatment is recommended.
    • For those with multiple episodes, indefinite treatment is often advised.
  • Side Effects:

Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS)
  • Common with first-generation antipsychotics, including symptoms like
    • Acute dystonia - Earliest, can occur within minutes of the injection (Option B)
    • Parkinson's - Occurs within days to weeks
    • Akathisia - Occurs within days to weeks (Option C)
  • Alternatives for management include dose reduction, antiparkinson medications, or switching to medications with lower EPS risk.

Tardive Dyskinesia (TD)

 

(Option D)
  • Affects 20-30% of patients on long-term first-generation antipsychotics, with higher risk in the elderly and those with cognitive or mood disorders.
  • Prevention strategies include using the lowest effective doses and switching to other medications like Clozapine.

Sedation & Postural hypotension

Especially with low-potency antipsychotics.

Long-term antipsychotic use can elevate prolactin levels, affecting sexual function and potentially leading to osteoporosis.

questions.text: OCPs are not protective for?
questions.solution:
OCPs are not protective for breast cancer.

 

Cancer Type

Effect of COC Use

Key Findings

Endometrial Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by ≥30%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for years after discontinuation.
  • More pronounced reduction seen in smokers, obese women, and those with low physical activity.

Ovarian Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 30–50%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for 10–15 years after stopping, even with short-term use (≥6 months).
  • Protection extends to BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers.

Colorectal Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 15–20%.

Breast Cancer

Increased Risk
  • COC use increases risk by 25%, especially in nulliparous women who start before age 24 and use it for >4 years.
  • If breast cancer develops, it is usually well-differentiated with a good prognosis.
  • The increased risk disappears after 10 years of stopping.

Cervical Cancer

Increased Risk
  • Prolonged COC use increases risk, particularly of adenocarcinoma of the cervix.
  • Women using COCs for ≥5 years have a higher risk, with risk increasing with longer duration.

questions.text: A renal biopsy image is shown. Identify the cells marked in the histological section.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Lacis cells

 

Explanation:

Lacis cells, also called extraglomerular mesangial cells or Goormaghtigh cells, are found within the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) of the kidney.

  • These cells are located between the afferent and efferent arterioles and the macula densa.
  • They play a role in signal transmission between the macula densa and juxtaglomerular cells, influencing renin secretion.
  • They are part of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and contribute to blood pressure regulation.


Juxtaglomerular Apparatus (JGA) and its Components

Component

Location

Function

Macula densa

Distal tubule near afferent arteriole

Senses sodium concentration & regulates renin secretion

Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells

Afferent arteriole

Secrete renin in response to low BP

Lacis cells (Extraglomerular mesangial cells)

Between the afferent & efferent arterioles

Facilitate communication between macula densa and JG cells

Podocytes

Visceral layer of Bowman's capsule

Filtration barrier in glomerulus

 


Macula densa (Option A): Incorrect because macula densa cells are found in the distal tubule and sense sodium concentration.

Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells (Option B): Incorrect because JG cells are located in the afferent arteriole and primarily secrete renin.

Podocytes (Option D): Incorrect because podocytes are specialized epithelial cells covering the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who delivered a healthy term baby one week ago is now presenting to the OBG clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling pale brownish vaginal discharge. What is the nature of this discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lochia Serosa

 

Explanation: Lochia Serosa is usually seen from the 5th to the 9th day of puerperium, the color of discharge is yellowish, pink, or pale brownish (Option B)

 

Lochia is the vaginal discharge seen in early puerperium due to the sloughing of decidual tissue. It has an offensive fishy smell and may last up to 35 days.

 

Depending upon the variation of the colour, the types of Lochia are:

Type of Lochia

Timing

Composition

Lochia Rubra -red

(Option A)

Seen in 1-4 days
  • Blood
  • Shreds of fetal membranes and decidua
  • Vernix caseosa
  • Lanugo and meconium.

Lochia Serosa-yellowish or

pink or pale brownish

(Option B)

5-9 days
  • Less RBC but more leukocytes
  • Wound exudate
  • Mucus from the cervix
  • Microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci)

Lochia Alba-pale white

(Option C)

10-15 days
  • Decidual cells
  • Leukocytes
  • Mucus
  • Cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells
  • Microorganisms.

 

Leukorrhea: Profuse white discharge might be seen in vaginitis, cervicitis, or subinvolution (Option D)

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage present in the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyaline cartilage

Explanation:

  • The image shows a glassy, bluish-white matrix with chondrocytes in lacunae
  • Hyaline cartilage is the most common type. It has a glassy, translucent matrix due to the fine collagen fibrils. Chondrocytes (cartilage cells) are scattered throughout the matrix, often appearing in small groups (isogenous groups) within lacunae (spaces).

 

Types of Cartilage

Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage (Yellow cartilage) (Option B)

Fibrocartilage (Option D)

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Articular cartilage (Option C): Articular cartilage is a specific type of hyaline cartilage covering the bones' surfaces in synovial joints. While it is a form of hyaline cartilage, the term "articular" refers to its location rather than a different type of cartilage.

questions.text: What is the key difference between Cisplatin and Carboplatin?

choices.text: Cisplatin is less neurotoxic than Carboplatin
Cisplatin causes fewer gastric issues compared to Carboplatin
Carboplatin is more neurotoxic than Cisplatin
Cisplatin has more nephrotoxic side effects compared to Carboplatin

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Cisplatin has more nephrotoxic side effects compared to Carboplatin

 

Explanation:

Cisplatin and Carboplatin are platinum-based chemotherapy agents, but Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic due to its accumulation in renal tubular cells.

  • Key Differences:
    • Cisplatin:
      • More nephrotoxic → Causes acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and requires aggressive hydration with mannitol or amifostine to reduce damage.
      • More neurotoxic and ototoxic → Causes peripheral neuropathy and sensorineural hearing loss (ototoxicity).
      • More severe nausea and vomiting.
    • Carboplatin:
      • Less nephrotoxic and does not require aggressive hydration.
      • Less neurotoxic compared to cisplatin.
      • More myelosuppressive (causes thrombocytopenia).

Cisplatin is known for its nephrotoxic effects, which can lead to acute kidney injury.

 

The management of cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity includes

  • Adequate i.v. fluids - Chloride diuresis (Cl inactivates cisplatin)
  • Mannitol - diuresis of inactivated cisplatin
  • Use of nephroprotective agents like amifostine (only i.v.)

 

  • Cisplatin is less neurotoxic than Carboplatin (Option A): Incorrect because Cisplatin is more neurotoxic (causing peripheral neuropathy).

 

  • Cisplatin causes fewer gastric issues compared to Carboplatin (Option B): Incorrect because Cisplatin causes more nausea and vomiting (highly emetogenic).

 

  • Carboplatin is more neurotoxic than Cisplatin (Option C): Incorrect because Cisplatin is more neurotoxic than Carboplatin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male experiences headache, nausea, and shortness of breath while trekking. The physician prescribes a drug to alleviate his symptoms. The drug administered primarily acts on which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)

 

Explanation:

The patient is experiencing symptoms of acute mountain sickness (AMS) due to hypoxia at high altitude. The drug commonly prescribed for AMS is acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, which primarily acts on the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron.

  • Mechanism of Acetazolamide in AMS:
    • Inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the PCT, leading to:
      • Decreased bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) reabsorption → metabolic acidosis
      • Increased renal excretion of bicarbonate → compensatory hyperventilation
    • This enhances ventilation and improves oxygenation, helping alleviate AMS symptoms.

 


Acetazolamide in AMS Symptom Alleviation

  • Inhibits kidney carbonic anhydrase.
  • Increases urine bicarbonate ions excretion → Metabolic acidosis.
  • Counteracts respiratory alkalosis from high altitude hyperventilation.
  • Improves oxygenation and alleviates AMS symptoms.

 

 

  • Loop of Henle (Option B) is incorrect because loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) act here by inhibiting Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ cotransport, but they are not used for AMS.

 

  • Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT) (Option C) is incorrect because thiazide diuretics act here by inhibiting Na⁺-Cl⁻ symport, but they do not correct AMS-related hypoxia.

 

  • Collecting Duct (CD) (Option D) is incorrect because the collecting duct is the site of aldosterone and ADH regulation, affected by potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone), which do not treat AMS.

questions.text: A 23 year old male epileptic patient presented with pain in right shoulder region. Examination revealed that right upper limb was abducted and externally rotated and the movements could not be performed. Which of the following is most likely diagnosed
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient's arm is abducted and externally rotated, which is a classic presentation of anterior shoulder dislocation (type: subglenoid dislocation).

 

Types of Shoulder dislocations:

 

Aspects

Anterior dislocation

Posterior dislocation

(Option D)

Inferior dislocation

(Option B)

Frequency

Most common

Not very common

Rare

Mechanism of Injury

Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder.

Occurs during seizures or convulsions.

  • A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm.
  • A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder.
  • A fall onto an outstretched hand.
  • Also called luxatio erecta.
  • Result from a severe hyper-abduction force.

Clinical presentation

Pain, swelling and movement restriction.

Tests

Duga’s test, Hamilton ruler test and Regimental badge test.

Callaway’s test and Regimental badge test

Bryant’s test

Arm Position

Abduction and external rotation

Adduction and internal rotation

Arm locked in hyperabduction with the hand positioned above the head.

X-ray Findings
  • The humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position).
  • "Hill-Sachs lesion" (compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head).

 
  • The humeral head is displaced posteriorly, appearing closer to the scapula.
  • ‘Light bulb sign’(humeral head appears rounded due to internal rotation).
  • ‘Rim sign’ (widening of the glenohumeral joint space).
  • ‘Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion’ (compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head).

 

The humeral head is displaced inferiorly below the glenoid cavity.

 

Management

Reduction techniques:

  • Kocher's method (Most commonly used)
  • Hippocrates method
  • Stimson’s technique

Reduction and immobility, followed by active exercises.


 
  • Closed reduction
  • Open reduction if soft tissue injuries are present
  • Re-examination after reduction to avoid neurovascular injuries.

Complications
  • Early:
    • Neurovascular injuries
    • Rotator cuff tear
  • Delayed:
    • Recurrence
    • Stiffness
    • Unreduced dislocation
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation
  • Neurovascular injuries
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation

 

 

Anterior Shoulder dislocation

Subtypes
  • Subglenoid: The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa.
  • Subclavicular: The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic: The humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity, which is rare.
  • Subcoracoid: The humeral head lies below the coracoid process.

Clinical findings
  • Loss of the deltoid contour (loss of shoulder roundness)
  • The shoulder is extended, abducted and externally rotated.

Clinical tests
  • Duga’s test is the inability to touch the opposite shoulder.
  • Hamilton ruler test is where the gap between the ruler and the arm is lost.
  • Callaway’s test is increased girth of the axilla on the dislocated side.
  • Bryant’s Test is where the anterior axillary fold is displaced downward on the affected side.
  • Regiment batch sign is loss of sensation due to axillary nerve damage.

Imaging
  • X-ray reveals that the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position)
  • An MRI is necessary to assess soft-tissue injuries and identify Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions, which are complications of shoulder dislocations and increase the risk of recurrence due to joint instability.

Management
  • Kocher's method (Most common method) is the reduction by traction, external rotation, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • In Hippocrates' method, the surgeon pulls the semi-abducted arm firmly while using his foot in the axilla as a fulcrum to reduce the dislocation.
  • Stimson’s technique is the reduction by applying weight for traction, using the body as counter traction.


 

Intrathoracic dislocation of shoulder (Option A): This is an extremely rare condition where the humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity. It is not commonly associated with the described clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 26 year old female was brought to ER post fire incidence. Her face and lower limbs were spared. Calculate the area of burn.
questions.solution:
Answer: D) 40-50%

 

Explanation:

Face & Lower Limbs are Spared → These are NOT included in the burn calculation.

Burned Areas:

  • Anterior Torso: 18%
  • Posterior Torso: 18%
  • Both Arms: 9% (each arm is 9%, but if only the front or back is affected, it would be 4.5% per arm)
  • Perineum: 1%

Total Burn Area Calculation:

  • Anterior Torso (18%) + Posterior Torso (18%) + Both Arms (9%) + Perineum (1%) = 46% TBSA

 

According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated:

Lower limb

13.5 x 2 = 27%
