questions.text: Which of the following drugs were not given for hypertension in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is teratogenic and causes fetal renal impairment, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and hypocalvaria. Therefore, it should be avoided at all stages of pregnancy.

 

Antihypertensive Treatment During Pregnancy

 

First-line drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Beta-blockers

Labetalol (Option C)

Preferred. Generally safe and effective

Calcium channel blockers

Nifedipine (Option D),

Amlodipine

Safe, less BP variability compared to labetalol

Alpha-2 agonist

Methyl dopa (Option A)

Safe but less effective in severe hypertension. It works by reducing sympathetic outflow and vascular resistance. However, it has sedative effects and may cause fatigue or depression.

 

Labetalol is commonly used to treat acute severe hypertension in pregnancy.

  • Initial IV dose: 10–20 mg, then 20–80 mg every 10–30 mins up to 300 mg.
  • Continuous IV infusion: 1–2 mg/min.
  • Fewer side effects than alternatives; less tachycardia.
  • Avoid in asthma, heart disease, compromised heart function, heart block, or bradycardia.

 

Second-line drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Vasodilators

Hydralazine

Reserved for cases with cardiac/renal dysfunction

 

Contraindicated drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

ACE inhibitors

Enalapril, Lisinopril

Associated with severe fetal malformations

Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Losartan, Valsartan

Not recommended at any point during pregnancy

 

Pre-existing Medication Management:

● ACE Inhibitors/ARBs: Discontinue immediately upon pregnancy recognition.

● Other Antihypertensives:

○ Mild/Moderate Hypertension: Some guidelines suggest discontinuation in the first trimester and restart if BP approaches severe range.

questions.text: A woman had a difficult labour. She complains of dribbling of urine 7 days after surgery. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of difficult labour followed by continuous leakage of urine from the vagina without micturition strongly suggests a Vesicovaginal fistula.

  • It's also the most common type of urinary fistula.
  • Obstructed Labor is the most common cause for the development of VVF in Developing countries. (Developed countries - Hysterectomy).

 

Vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF):

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal passage that develops between the bladder and the vagina, leading to the continuous and involuntary discharge of urine through the vagina.
  • This condition typically results from prolonged obstructed labour or pelvic surgery complications, where tissues between the bladder and the vagina are damaged, causing the formation of the fistula.

 

Investigations of genitourinary fistulas:

 

Cystoscopy with dye test
  • It involves inserting a dye solution (methylene blue) to confirm the diagnosis.

MRI or CT Scan
  • These imaging modalities may be used to assess complex cases or to plan surgical repair, providing detailed anatomical information.

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP)
  • (IVP) is a diagnostic imaging test that is not typically used as a primary method to diagnose vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF).


Management:

 

Conservative

Surgical
  • Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • In 10 per cent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small.




 

Transvaginal Repair:

  • This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall.
  • It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favourable positions that allow for direct access and closure.

Transabdominal Repair:

  • Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach.
  • This can be done via laparotomy (open surgery) or laparoscopy (minimally invasive surgery).
  • Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications.

 

Ureterovaginal fistula (Option B): This involves an abnormal communication between the ureter and vagina, usually due to gynaecological surgeries or obstetric complications. It presents with leakage of urine through the vagina but is less common compared to vesicovaginal fistula in the context of obstructed labour.

 

Rectovaginal fistula (Option C) is an abnormal connection that forms between the rectum and the vagina and presents with the passage of rectal contents through the vagina, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, passing air, bleeding, and frank stool.


Vesicouterine fistula (Option D): This involves communication between the bladder and uterus. It is less common and typically presents with continuous urinary incontinence and amenorrhea.

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

A history of chronic smoking and decreased FEV₁% (forced expiratory volume in 1 second as a percentage of forced vital capacity) are hallmarks of obstructive lung disease, with COPD being the most probable diagnosis.

  • Key Features of COPD:
    • Chronic smoking history is the most significant risk factor.
    • Obstructive pattern on spirometry:
      • ↓ FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 sec)
      • ↓ FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%) → hallmark of airflow obstruction
    • Progressive dyspnoea, chronic cough, sputum production
    • Irreversible airflow limitation

Features of Obstructive Diseases:

  1. Total Lung Capacity is normal or increased
  2. Residual Volume is elevated due to trapping of air during expiration
  3. The ratio of RV/TLC is increased
  4. Vital Capacity frequently decreases (not due to decreased lung volumes but increased RV).
  5. FEV is less than 80% of TLC
  6. FEV/FVC decreases
  7. MMFR (Maximum Mid-Expiratory Flow Rate) decreases

 

Emphysema:

Chronic infection

↓

Impaired mucus clearance + Excess mucus secretion + Inflammatory edema

↓

Bronchiolar obstruction

↓

Air trapping and Alveolar damage

↓

Elevated RV and TLC

 

Examples of obstructive lung disease:

  • Asthma
  • COPD (Chronic bronchitis and emphysema)
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Bronchiolitis
  • Cystic fibrosis

 

Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option B) is incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease, which shows decreased FVC but normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio.


 

Interstitial Lung Disease (Option C) is incorrect because interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) cause a restrictive pattern, with normal or increased FEV₁/FVC rather than a decreased ratio.


 

Asthma (Option D) is incorrect because while asthma also causes obstructive airway disease with a low FEV₁%, it is typically reversible with bronchodilators, unlike COPD, which is progressive and largely irreversible.

questions.text: A baby is born with microcephaly, intracerebral calcification and chorioretinitis. Which teratogenic infections is the mother suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Toxoplasma

Explanation:

The presence of characteristic intracranial calcifications, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis are features of congenital toxoplasmosis.

Etiology and Clinical Features of Congenital Toxoplasmosis:

Category

Details

Etiology

Primary maternal infection with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy is the primary cause

Risk Factors

Infection during the first trimester: severe outcomes, lower transmission rate (~17%)

Infection during third trimester: milder outcomes, higher transmission rate (~65%)

Clinical Features

CNS: Hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, seizures, developmental delays, microcephaly in severe brain damage

Ocular: Chorioretinitis, vision impairment, strabismus, photophobia, epiphora

Systemic: Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, prematurity

Other: Jaundice, thrombocytopenia, rash, hearing loss

Diagnosis:

Diagnosis Method

Details

Fetal Ultrasound

Performed every 2 weeks during gestation after diagnosis of maternal infection.

PCR Analysis of Amniotic Fluid

Used for prenatal diagnosis of fetal infection.

Serologic Tests

Persistent or rising titers in dye/IFA tests, positive IgM-ELISA.

Newborn Evaluation

General, ophthalmologic, and neurologic exams; head CT scan for intracranial calcifications.

CSF Analysis

Lumbar puncture with analysis for Toxoplasma-specific IgG and IgM, total IgG, cells, glucose, and protein.

Toxoplasma Isolation

Isolation from placenta, infant’s leukocytes, and CSF using PCR

Management:

Treatment

Details

Pyrimethamine and Sulfadiazine, along with Folinic Acid (Calcium Leucovorin)

Synergistic action against Toxoplasma gondii. Standard treatment for congenital toxoplasmosis. Folinic Acid is administered to prevent bone marrow suppression caused by pyrimethamine

Spiramycin

Used in pregnant women during the first trimester to prevent vertical transmission.

Monitoring

Regular leukocyte counts twice weekly to detect neutropenia and other hematologic effects.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection (Option B) can also cause intracranial calcifications; however, these are more commonly seen in a periventricular pattern. While there is some overlap, the calcifications in congenital toxoplasmosis are often more diffuse.

Varicella (Option C) presents with microcephaly and chorioretinitis. But it is associated with microphthalmia, cataracts, cortical atrophy, seizures, mental retardation, etc. as well.

Rubella (Option D) presents with patent ductus arteriosus, bilateral cataracts, and salt & pepper retinopathy, which are classical signs of congenital rubella syndrome

questions.text: Following image denote which side of placenta?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts fetal surface of placenta.

 

The placenta has 2 surfaces:

Maternal surface (Basal plate)
(Options B & D)

Fetal surface (Chorionic plate)
  • Adherent to the uterine wall.
  • It is rough, dull and dark red in colour
  • It is divided into cotyledons by decidual septum.
  • It helps anchor the placenta to the uterus.
  • Contains maternal blood sinus.
  • Receives blood from spiral arteries.
  • The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal surface.
  • It is smooth, shiny and bluish-purple.
  • It is covered with amnion.
  • Takes part in gaseous and nutritional exchange.
  • Highly vascular with fetal capillaries.
  • Facilitates nutritional exchange via chorionic villi.


Decidual surface (Option C) refers to the decidua basalis, the maternal tissue that interacts with the placenta. It is not an independent placental surface but contributes to the maternal side.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of typhus, an antigen of Proteus is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heterophile antigen

Explanation: Proteus antigens are classified as heterophile antigens because they cross-react with antibodies produced against Rickettsia in the diagnosis of typhus.

Weil-Felix Test:

  • Weil-Felix Test is a heterophile agglutination test that works on the principle of rickettsial antibodies showing antigenic cross-reactivity with Proteus antigens (OX 19, OX 2 and OX K strains).
  • It is a tube agglutination test where serial dilutions of a patient's serum are treated with non-motile strains of P. vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and P. mirabilis OX K.

Disease

Agglutination Test Result

Epidemic and endemic typhus

Mainly agglutinates with OX19; sometimes with OX2

Tick-borne Spotted Fever

Antibodies to both OX19 and OX2 elevated.

Scrub Typhus

Raised antibodies to OXK

Rickettsial Pox, Q Fever, Ehrlichiosis, Bartonellosis

Negative test
  • False-positive titer - Due to underlying Proteus infection. Hence, fourfold rise of antibody titer in paired sera is better than a single high titer.
  • False-negative titer - Due to excess antibodies in the patient's sera (prozone phenomenon). This can be obviated by testing with serial dilutions of the patient's serum.

Sequestered antigens (Option A) are normally hidden from the immune system due to anatomical barriers (e.g., myelin basic protein, lens proteins of the eye, sperm-associated antigens). When exposed after trauma, infection, or inflammation, they may trigger autoimmune reactions (e.g., sympathetic ophthalmia, multiple sclerosis).

Superantigens (Option B) are highly potent immune activators that bypass normal antigen presentation by directly binding to MHC class II molecules and T-cell receptors, leading to massive cytokine release and systemic immune activation. Examples include:

  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins (food poisoning)
  • Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1)
  • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (scarlet fever, toxic shock syndrome)
     

Isoantigens (or alloantigens) (Option C) are antigens that vary among individuals of the same species, such as blood group antigens (ABO, Rh) and HLA antigens. These play a role in blood transfusion compatibility and organ transplantation but are not relevant in the diagnosis of typhus.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the OPD with hearing loss. On examination:

 

Rinne test- Positive in the left ear and negative in the right ear

Weber's test - lateralization towards the left

Bone conduction test - Reduced in the right ear and similar in the left ear.

 

Interpret the findings.

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in right ear
Conductive hearing loss in left ear
Conductive hearing loss in right ear.

questions.solution:
The given Rinne test, Weber’s test, and bone conduction test help differentiate between sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and conductive hearing loss (CHL).

Interpretation of the tests:

 

Test

Conductive Loss

Sensorineural Loss

Normal Hearing

Rinne

Negative (BC > AC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Positive (AC > BC)

Weber

Lateralises to worse ear

Lateralises to better ear

Heard equally

Absolute Bone Conduction

(ABC)

Hears as long as the examiner

Hears for a shorter duration

Hears as long as the examiner

Schwabach

Lengthened

Reduced

Normal
  1. Rinne Test:
    • Positive in the left ear → Air conduction (AC) > Bone conduction (BC) → Normal or SNHL in the left ear.
    • Negative in the right ear → Bone conduction > Air conduction → Conductive hearing loss (CHL) in the right ear OR a false negative due to profound SNHL.
  2. Weber Test:
    • Lateralization to the left ear → This suggests:
      • Conductive hearing loss in the left ear OR
      • Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear (since Weber lateralizes to the better ear in SNHL).
  3. Bone Conduction Test:
    • Reduced in right ear → Suggests sensorineural involvement in the right ear.
    • Similar in left ear → No significant sensorineural loss in the left ear.

Final Conclusion:

  • Since bone conduction is reduced in the right ear, it indicates sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the right ear.
  • Weber lateralizing to the left ear further supports SNHL in the right ear (since in SNHL, Weber localizes to the better-hearing ear).

questions.text: Which of the following is the duration of abstinence post vasectomy?
questions.solution:
A man should continue using contraception for at least 3 months (or after 20 ejaculations) post-vasectomy until semen analysis confirms azoospermia. This is necessary because viable sperm may still be present in the vas deferens after the procedure.

 

7 months (Option B) is incorrect because sperm clearance is usually complete within 3 months, and waiting 7 months is unnecessary.

8 months (Option C) is incorrect as sperm usually clear well before this duration.

5 months (Option D) is incorrect because guidelines recommend 3 months as the standard duration for post-vasectomy contraception use.

questions.text: What type of fracture is caused by a hammer?
questions.solution:
A hammer is a heavy, blunt object that delivers a focused impact on the skull. This results in a depressed fracture, where the bone is pushed inward at the point of impact, creating a localized depression or indentation.


 

Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture



 

Ring Fracture

(Option D)

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.



 

Ring fracture

 

Hinge fracture



 

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option A)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate was brought to the hospital with a complaint of non-bilious vomiting. While examining the baby, the physician noted a lump in the left epigastric region, which showed movement while feeding. What is the likely diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IHPS

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is most likely congenital/ idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 to 6 weeks of age.

Risk Factors of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

Genetic Factors
  • White race of northern European descent
  • Male sex
  • Familial History: Higher risk in offspring of mothers with CHPS (20% for sons, 10% for daughters)
  • Twin Studies: Higher concordance in monozygotic twins suggests a genetic component
  • Blood Groups: Infants with B and O blood groups.

Environmental Factors
  • Erythromycin Use: Especially if administered within the first two weeks of life
  • Higher incidence in infants whose mothers used macrolides during pregnancy or breastfeeding, particularly in females.

Other Associated Factors
  • Other Congenital Defects Syndromes: Occasionally associated with tracheoesophageal fistula and hypoplasia or agenesis of the inferior labial frenulum.
  • Associated with eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Apert syndrome, Zellweger syndrome, trisomy 18, Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome, and Cornelia de Lange syndrome.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age.
    • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
      • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
      • Pyloric length > 14 mm
      • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

Characteristic findings of Contrast studies in CHPS

Findings

Description

String Sign

A thin line of contrast material passes through the narrowed pyloric channel, indicating severe narrowing due to hypertrophied muscle.

Shoulder Sign

A bulge of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle into the gastric antrum gives the appearance of a “shoulder.”

Double Tract Sign

Parallel streaks of contrast material within the narrowed pyloric channel suggest the presence of a narrow passage for contrast flow.

Mushroom sign

Bulging of the hypertrophic muscle into the 1st part of the duodenum.

Esophageal atresia (Option A) will have bilious vomiting and does not present with any mass in the epigastrium.

Duodenal atresia (Option B) presents with bilious vomiting immediately after birth. This is not the given scenario.

Intussusception (Option D) presents with a sausage-shaped abdominal mass but is not associated with vomiting. It is more characteristically associated with red currant jelly stools.

questions.text: Chronic malnutrition is best measured by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Height for age

Explanation:

Chronic malnutrition is best measured by height for age.

WHO Classification of Malnutrition

Moderately underweight

Weight-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely underweight

Weight-for-age is < -3 SDs.

Moderately wasted

Weight-for-length/height is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely wasted

Weight-for-length/height is < -3 SDs.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition:
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDs.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDs.

Weight for age (Option B) is used to determine whether a child is moderately or severely underweight.

Weight for height (Option C) is used to determine the severity of acute malnutrition and wasting.

Body mass index (Option D) is used to determine the severity of acute malnutrition.

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness and is diagnosed with a Pancoast tumor. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
A Pancoast tumor is a type of lung cancer that occurs at the apex of the lung and can invade nearby structures, including the brachial plexus, sympathetic chain, and adjacent ribs. The tumor is commonly associated with a condition known as Horner’s syndrome due to its involvement with the sympathetic nervous system.

Horner’s Syndrome

  • Horner’s syndrome is caused by a lesion of the sympathetic chain, which clinically manifests as ipsilateral miosis, facial anhidrosis, and ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).
  • Causes:

Central lesions

Preganglionic

Postganglionic

  • Brainstem pathology (tumours, vascular diseases, demyelinating disorders)
  • Spinal cord tumours
  • Pancoast tumour
  • Carotid and Aortic aneurysms
  • Neck lesions
  • Atherosclerosis of ICA (internal carotid artery))
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours
  • Cavernous sinus pathology
  • Cluster headaches

 

  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos.
    • Anhydrosis (loss of sweating): It is seen in preganglionic lesions.
    • Absence of cilio-spinal reflex (involuntary response where the pupil of the eye dilates in response to painful stimuli applied to the skin of the neck or upper back)
  • Acute Horner’s syndrome with associated ipsilateral neck or facial pain requires urgent imaging of the neck for evaluation of a carotid dissection

questions.text: Identify the defect in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Open neural tube defect

Explanation:

The given image depicts a newborn with an open neural tube defect, specifically rachischisis or myeloschisis, which is a severe form of spina bifida where the neural tissue is exposed without skin or meningeal covering.


 

Neural tube defects:

Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

 

Meningoencephalocele (Option B): Incorrect because a meningoencephalocele is a sac-like protrusion of meninges and brain tissue through a skull defect, typically in the occipital region.

Occult Spina Bifida (Option C): Incorrect because occult spina bifida is a closed defect where the vertebral arch fails to fuse, but the skin remains intact, often presenting with subtle external markers like a tuft of hair or dimple.

Encephalocele (Option D): is a rare birth defect that occurs when the neural tube doesn't close completely during fetal development. This results in a sac-like protrusion of brain tissue or membranes through a hole in the skull.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Gluconeogenesis

 

Explanation:

  • Alcohol metabolism increases NADH/NAD+ ratio:
    • Ethanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to excessive NADH production.
  • Inhibition of Gluconeogenesis:
    • High NADH shifts metabolic balance, preventing conversion of lactate to pyruvate and malate to oxaloacetate, both of which are essential for gluconeogenesis.
  • Hypoglycemia Risk:
    • After exercise and fasting, glycogen stores are depleted.
    • The body relies on gluconeogenesis for glucose, but alcohol blocks this pathway, leading to hypoglycemia after drinking.

Alcohol-Induced Hypoglycemia

Feature

Effect of Alcohol

Key Mechanism

↑ NADH inhibits gluconeogenesis

Primary Effect

↓ Glucose production → Hypoglycemia

Clinical Features

Weakness, dizziness, confusion, seizures

Risk Factors

Fasting, exercise, malnutrition, chronic alcoholism

Treatment

IV dextrose, thiamine in alcoholics
  • Glycogenolysis (Option B): Incorrect because alcohol does not directly inhibit glycogen breakdown. However, after prolonged fasting, glycogen stores are already depleted.
  • Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt (Option C): Incorrect because this pathway primarily generates NADPH for anabolic processes and does not significantly contribute to blood glucose levels.
  • Ketone Body Formation (Option D): Incorrect because alcohol metabolism can actually promote ketogenesis, especially in chronic alcoholism, rather than inhibiting it.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of decreased glucose, increased protein, and neutrophilic pleocytosis points towards a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis.

Ceftriaxone is the first-line antibiotic for treatment of bacterial meningitis.

Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Classic Triad of Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

CSF Findings
  • Opening pressure: Elevated
  • Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs)
  • Protein: Elevated
  • Glucose: Decreased
  • Gross appearance: Turbid

Treatment
  • Immediate Management:
    • Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone
    • Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Ampicillin (Option A) is primarily used in Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, which is more common in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised patients. It is not first-line for typical bacterial meningitis in healthy adults.

Penicillin (Option C) was historically used for Neisseria meningitidis but is not sufficient as monotherapy due to increasing resistance. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage.

Vancomycin (Option D) is used in combination with Ceftriaxone when penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae is suspected, but it is not sufficient alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is the schedule of the OPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is administered as part of the routine immunisation schedule at 6, 10, and 14 weeks along with DPT and other vaccines. Additionally, a booster dose is given at 16–24 months.

 

Differences between IPV and OPV:

 

Characteristic

IPV (salk type)

OPV (sabin type)

Type of vaccine

Killed formalised virus

Live attenuated virus

Mode of administration

S/C or IM (0.5 mL)

Oral (2 drops)

Type of immunity

Only humoral

Humoral and intestinal

Prevention of

Paralysis

Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection

Control of epidemics

Not useful

Effective

Storage & transport

Less stringent conditions

Requires sub-zero temperatures

Shelf life

Longer

Short

VAPP (Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio)

Zero incidences

1 per 1 million vaccines

 

  • Schedule of OPV: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years; 2 oral drops
  • Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm.
    fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose.
  • From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

questions.text: A patient sample positive for Infectious Hepatitis B. Choose the correct marker for thiscondition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HBsAg + HBe

Explanation: The correct marker for Infectious Hepatitis B is HBsAg + HBe, as HBsAg indicates active infection, and HBeAg signifies high infectivity.

questions.text: Dehydration is more severe in infants compared to adults. Which of the following is a true statement about infants?

choices.text: Extracellular fluid (ECF) is more than intracellular fluid (ICF)
Intracellular fluid (ICF) is more than extracellular fluid (ECF)
Total body water in infants is more than in adults

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Total body water in infants is more than in adults

 

Explanation:

Infants have a higher total body water (TBW) percentage compared to adults, making them more susceptible to dehydration.

  • Total body water (TBW) composition:
    • Infants: ~75-80% of body weight
    • Adults: ~55-60% of body weight
  • Higher water turnover: Infants lose water more rapidly due to higher metabolic rates, increased insensible losses, and immature renal function.

Total Body Water (TBW) Composition:

  • 90% of body weight in early fetal life.
  • 75% of body weight at birth.
  • 60% of body weight by the end of the first year, remaining consistent until puberty.
  • After puberty, males have slightly more TBW compared to females.

 

Preterm vs. Term Neonates:

  • Preterm neonates have a higher TBW compared to term neonates.

 

TBW Distribution:

  • TBW is divided into:
    • Extracellular Fluid (ECF)
    • Intracellular Fluid (ICF)
  • The equation is: TBW = ECF + ICF
    • ECF = plasma + interstitial fluid

 

ECF and ICF Changes:

  • In fetuses and newborns, ECF > ICF volume.
  • After birth, ECF volume decreases and ICF volume increases.

 

Extracellular fluid (ECF) is more than intracellular fluid (ICF) (Option A) is incorrect because, while infants have a higher ECF proportion at birth (~40%), ICF eventually exceeds ECF as they grow.


 

Intracellular fluid (ICF) is more than extracellular fluid (ECF) (Option B) is incorrect at birth, but becomes true after the first year. In neonates, ECF is initially greater than ICF.


 

Extracellular fluid equals intracellular fluid (Option D) is incorrect because ECF and ICF are not equal at any stage; there is always a shift, with ICF becoming dominant after infancy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with mid-arm circumference of 105mm, upon providing therapeutic food, eagerly completed all of it. This patient is considered under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uncomplicated SAM

Explanation:

  • In this case, the 4-year-old child has a MUAC of 105 mm (10.5 cm), which falls below the Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) threshold of 115 mm (11.5 cm), indicating severe malnutrition.
  • The child eagerly consumed the therapeutic food, successfully passing the appetite test.
  • There is no severe edema or medical complications requiring inpatient care, and no immediate life-threatening conditions.

Based on these findings, the child is classified as having Uncomplicated SAM and can be managed with supervised home-based therapeutic feeding.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in Children (6 to 59 months of age):

Criteria

Details

Diagnostic Criteria for SAM

Assessment for Complications

Check for the following complications:

  • Severe edema (+++)
  • Low appetite (fails appetite test)
  • Medical complications
  • Presence of one or more danger signs (as per IMNCI guidelines)

Management Approach

Based on the presence or absence of complications:

  • If NO complications → Uncomplicated SAM → Supervised home management
  • If YES (complications present) → Complicated SAM → Inpatient management in a healthcare facility

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a refractive error of -2D in the right eye and +1D in the left eye. Fundus examination reveals normal visual acuity and retinal findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anisometropia is a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive power between the two eyes. In this case:

  • Right Eye (RE): -2D (Total refractive power: 62D → 60 + 2D)
  • Left Eye (LE): +1D (Total refractive power: 59D → 60 - 1D)
  • Difference in refractive power = 62D - 59D = 3D, which is greater than 2.5D, making it clinically significant anisometropia.

Anisometropia:

is a term used when the dioptric power of both eyes is not the same, and is significant if > 2.5D difference.

 

Myopia (Option A): Myopia (nearsightedness) is present in the right eye (-2D), but the left eye has hyperopia (+1D). The diagnosis should reflect the difference in refractive power rather than just the presence of myopia.

 

Hyperopia (Option B): Hyperopia (farsightedness) is present in the left eye (+1D), but since the right eye has myopia, this case is best classified as anisometropia rather than simple hyperopia.

 

Amblyopia (Option D): Amblyopia (lazy eye) can develop due to anisometropia if left untreated, but the question does not indicate decreased visual acuity. Therefore, anisometropia is the more accurate primary diagnosis at this stage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-MuSK antibodies

 

Explanation:

  • MuSK is essential for clustering AChRs at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies are found in AChR-negative patients, often presenting with bulbar muscle weakness (affecting speech and swallowing).

Autoantibodies in Myasthenia Gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness due to disrupted neuromuscular transmission.

Types of Autoantibodies

Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)
  • Diagnostic Tests
    • Repetitive Nerve Stimulation: Shows a decremental response (decline in muscle activity with repeated stimulation), indicating faulty neuromuscular transmission.
    • Blood Tests: Detect the presence of AChR and MuSK antibodies.

Anti-dsDNA antibodies (Option A): Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not associated with neuromuscular transmission issues.

 

Anti-TPO antibodies (Option C): Linked with autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto’s thyroiditis).

 

Anti-Ro antibodies (Option D): Found in Sjogren’s syndrome and neonatal lupus, not relevant to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was admitted with respiratory distress. CT showed a nasal polyp with fluid collection in the sinus. Drainage of which of the following is obstructed?
questions.solution:
The maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus via the ostium located high on its medial wall. When a nasal polyp is present, it can obstruct this drainage pathway, leading to fluid accumulation in the maxillary sinus, as seen on CT.

 

The maxillary sinus or the Antrum of Highmore, is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla.

  • Shape - Pyramidal
  • Size - 15mL
  • Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose
  • Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone

 

Relations:

  • Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla.
  • Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meatuses and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity.
  • Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit
  • Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oro antral fistula.

Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery.

Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein.

Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes.

Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2).

Other Options:

 

Ethmoidal Sinus (Option A): Drains into the middle meatus (anterior ethmoids) or superior meatus (posterior ethmoids); obstruction causes ethmoid sinusitis.

 

Sphenoidal Sinus (Option B): Drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess; obstruction leads to sphenoid sinusitis, often with deep headaches.

 

Frontal Sinus (Option C): Drains into the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct; obstruction causes frontal sinusitis, often with forehead pain.

questions.text: Which adverse effect of Bleomycin is exacerbated by radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Pulmonary toxicity

 

Explanation:

Bleomycin-induced pulmonary toxicity is the most significant adverse effect, and it is exacerbated by radiation exposure (a phenomenon known as radiation recall pneumonitis).

  • Mechanism:
    • Bleomycin generates free radicals, leading to oxidative damage and fibrosis in the lungs.
    • The lungs have low bleomycin hydrolase activity, making them more susceptible to damage.
    • Radiation exposure further increases oxidative stress and inflammatory responses, worsening lung injury.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Cumulative bleomycin dose >400 units
    • Concurrent oxygen therapy (risk of oxygen toxicity)
    • Prior or concurrent radiation therapy
    • Older age and renal impairment
  • Clinical Features:
    • Progressive dyspnoea, non-productive cough
    • Interstitial pneumonitis → pulmonary fibrosis
    • Restrictive lung disease with ↓ DLCO (diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide)

Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that is well-known for its association with pulmonary toxicity, including pulmonary fibrosis which occurs as follows:

 

 

Gastric toxicity (Option B) is incorrect because bleomycin does not significantly affect the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Neural toxicity (Option C) is incorrect because bleomycin does not cause neurotoxicity (unlike vincristine, which affects nerves).

 

Hepatotoxicity (Option D) is incorrect because bleomycin has minimal liver toxicity compared to other chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is the timing at which the triphenyl tetrazolium chloride can elicit findings post MI
questions.solution:
• Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining is used in experimental pathology to detect myocardial infarction (MI) by differentiating viable myocardium from infarcted tissue. TTC is a redox indicator that stains viable myocardial tissue brick red, while infarcted tissue, which lacks dehydrogenase activity, remains pale or unstained.
  • The earliest time at which TTC staining can reliably detect infarcted myocardial tissue is around 3 hours post-MI. Before this period, ischemic changes may not be extensive enough to produce a clear difference in staining.


 

1hr and 30 mins (Options A and B): At these early stages, myocardial injury is still evolving, and enzyme depletion is insufficient to produce a clear contrast with TTC staining.

Immediately (Option D ): TTC staining is not effective immediately after the onset of ischemia, as cellular enzyme activity has not yet deteriorated significantly.

questions.text: A disease with mitochondrial inheritance is inherited from which family member?
questions.solution:
• Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal inheritance pattern, meaning that only the mother passes mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) to her offspring.
  • This occurs because mitochondria are inherited exclusively from the egg, and sperm do not contribute mitochondria during fertilization.

 

Mitochondrial Inheritance Disorders:

Inheritance Pattern
  • Maternal inheritance: All children of an affected female inherit the disease.
  • Homoplasmy: Presence of mtDNA which is either all wild type or all mutated.
  • Heteroplasmy: Presence of both wild type (normal) and mutated mtDNA in the same individual.
  • Threshold effect: Minimum percentage of mutated mtDNA required for disease manifestation. In the presence of heteroplasmy, the threshold effect leads to variability in clinical expression across different tissues and mtDNA mutations.

Examples (Mnemonic: KLMNOP)
  1. Kearns-Sayre syndrome- Pigmentary retinopathy, cerebellar ataxia, heart block
  2. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy- Subacute painless bilateral visual failure
  3. MELAS- Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic acidosis, Stroke-like episodes
  4. MERRF- Myoclonic epilepsy, Seizures, Ataxia
  5. NARP- Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis pigmentosa
  6. CPEO- Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia, Bilateral Ptosis
  7. Pearson syndrome- Sideroblastic anemia of childhood, pancytopenia, pancreatic involvement

questions.text: During a forensic examination, a skull bone was brought by police whose cephalic index came out to be 85. Skull bone belongs to which race?
questions.solution:
Since the given cephalic index is 85, which is in the brachycephalic range, the skull most likely belongs to the Mongoloid race.

 

Anthropometric measurements, such as the cephalic index (CI), are valuable in determining ancestry, which assists forensic teams in narrowing down the possible identity of the deceased.

 

  • The cephalic index is calculated as:

CI = (Maximum Skull Breadth/Maximum Skull Length)*100

 

  • The skull breadth is measured between the two parietal eminences and the length is measured between the glabella and the external occipital protuberances with a calipers and not a mesuring tape.

 

Skull Shape

Cephalic Index (CI)

Population

Dolichocephalic

(Long-headed)

70-74.99

Pure Aryans, Aborigines, African (Negroid) (Options A, B)

Mesaticephalic

(Medium-headed)

75-79.99

European (Caucasoid), Chinese, Indians. (Option C)

Brachycephalic

(Short-headed)

80-84.99

East Asian (Mongoloid)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with tingling sensation of lateral 3 digits with loss of sensation of base of thumb on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Which is the nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radial nerve

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with:
     
    • Tingling of lateral 3 digits
       
    • Loss of sensation at the base (root) of the thumb on the dorsal aspect
       
  • These findings are best explained by involvement of the superficial branch of the radial nerve, which provides:
     
    • Cutaneous sensation to the dorsum of the hand, especially the base of the thumb and proximal parts of the lateral 3½ fingers, excluding the fingertips.
       
  • The tingling in the dorsal aspect of the lateral 3 digits may also be due to involvement of the proximal dorsal hand region, which is supplied by the radial nerve, not the median nerve.
     
  • The median nerve supplies the palmar aspect and the distal dorsal phalanges (fingertips) of the lateral 3½ digits, not the base of the thumb dorsally.
     

Sensory Supply of the Dorsal and Ventral Aspects of the Palm and Fingers:

Region

Nerve

Area Supplied

Ventral (Palmar) Aspect

Lateral 3½ fingers + lateral palm

Median nerve

Palmar surface of thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of ring finger + palm

Medial 1½ fingers + medial palm

Ulnar nerve

Palmar surface of little finger and medial half of ring finger + palm

Thenar eminence (skin)

Median nerve

Over the base of thumb (root of thumb, palmar side)

Hypothenar eminence

Ulnar nerve

Over the base of little finger

Dorsal Aspect

Lateral 3½ fingertips (nail beds)

Root (base) of thumb
