Ulnar nerve (Option B): Incorrect. Supplies the medial 1½ digits, which are not involved in this case.
 

Median nerve (Option C): Incorrect. Supplies palmar aspect and distal dorsal fingertips of lateral 3½ digits. It does not supply the dorsal root of the thumb, which is involved here.
 

AIN (Option D): Incorrect. Purely motor nerve. No cutaneous distribution.

questions.text: A 35 y/o asthmatic patient is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure. Which induction agent and muscle relaxant combination is safest for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ketamine and Vecuronium

 

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is beneficial in asthmatics as it provides analgesia and induces bronchodilation without significant hemodynamic instability.
  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that does not release histamine, making it safe for use in asthmatic patients.

Anaesthesia in Asthmatics

  • IV Induction Agent:
    • Propofol: Preferred for stable patients, promotes bronchodilation.
    • Ketamine: Ideal for hemodynamically unstable asthmatics, promotes bronchodilation.
  • Muscle Relaxant:
    • Vecuronium, Rocuronium, Cis-atracurium: Safe for use in asthmatics, no significant histamine release.
    • Pancuronium: Releases low levels of histamine.
  • Inhalational Agent:
    • Sevoflurane, Isoflurane, Halothane: Ideal choices as they depress airway reflexes and relax bronchial smooth muscle.
    • Desflurane: This should be avoided due to airway irritation and increased airway resistance.

Propofol and Succinylcholine (Option A): Succinylcholine may provoke bronchospasm.

 

Ketamine and d-tubocurarine (Option B): d-tubocurarine releases histamine, which can trigger bronchospasm.

 

Thiopental and Rocuronium (Option D): Thiopental has slower recovery times and can cause respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with multiple burn injuries involving the entire head, neck & upper limb. What is the percentage of burn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 25-30%

 

Explanation:

 

In children, the total body surface area (TBSA) percentages differ from adults due to the larger head-to-body ratio. According to the Rule of Nines adjusted for children and the Lund and Browder chart:

  • The entire head and neck account for approximately 18% of the TBSA in a 3-year-old child.

  • Each upper limb accounts for approximately 9% of the TBSA.

Adding these together:
18% (head and neck) + 9% (one upper limb) = 27%

 

According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated:

 

 

Adults

Children

Infants

Head & neck

9%

18%

20%

Front of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Back of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Lower limb

18 x 2 = 36%

13.5 x 2 = 27%

10 x 2 = 20%

Upper limb

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Perineum

1%

1%

  

 

40-44% (Option B): This value overestimates the burn area. A 40-44% burn would imply involvement of larger or additional body areas beyond the head, neck, and one upper limb, such as parts of the trunk or both upper limbs.

18-20% (Option C): This value roughly corresponds to the head and neck alone, without including the upper limb. Since the upper limb is also involved, the percentage should be higher.

5-10% (Option D): This severely underestimates the burn size. The entire head and neck alone exceed 10%, so including one upper limb must be substantially more.

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron has the lowest osmolality under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Early distal tubule

 

Explanation:

The early distal tubule has the lowest osmolality under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

  • Mechanism:
    • ADH increases water reabsorption in the collecting duct and late distal tubule, concentrating the urine.
    • The descending limb of the loop of Henle is highly permeable to water but not solutes, leading to an increase in osmolality.
    • In contrast, the early distal tubule is impermeable to water, but actively reabsorbs NaCl, making the tubular fluid hypotonic.
    • As a result, the lowest osmolality is found in the early distal tubule (~100mOsm/kg), even in the presence of ADH.

 

 

 

Descending limb of the loop of Henle (Option B) is incorrect because it is highly permeable to water and allows water to leave, increasing osmolality (~1200 mOsm/kg in the medullary region).

 

Collecting duct (Option C) is incorrect because under ADH influence, the collecting duct becomes highly water-permeable, leading to urine concentration (osmolality can reach >1200 mOsm/kg).

 

Late distal tubule (Option D) is incorrect because it is more permeable to water in the presence of ADH, leading to an increase in osmolality compared to the early distal tubule.

questions.text: Patient with HIV presenting with bouts of cough and fever. Which medium is appropriate for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium

Explanation: A patient with HIV presenting with cough and fever raises suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), which is common in immunocompromised individuals. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is a specialized culture medium used to isolate Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Lab Investigations for TB:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
    • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
    • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
    • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
    • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
    • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
    • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

Tinsdale medium (Option A) is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria.

MacConkey agar (Option C) is used for gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella.

Loeffler serum slope (LSS) (Option D) enhances the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A patient presents with the palsy of the face as shown. Which of the following is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 7th nerve palsy

Explanation:

 

The image presents a clinical case of facial palsy. The child's facial asymmetry, particularly the drooping of one side of the face, suggests a lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, commonly known as Bell’s palsy.

 

Bell’s palsy:

Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir (Adult doses)
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

 

3rd N. Palsy (Option B): Affects the oculomotor nerve (CN III), causing ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and pupil involvement, not facial asymmetry.

 

Erb’s Palsy (Option C): A brachial plexus injury affecting arm movement, not facial muscles.

 

Orbicularis Oculi Palsy (Option D): Would only affect eyelid closure, not the entire face.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred for management of diabetes in a patient with cardiac and renal failure?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) SGLT2 inhibitors

 

Explanation:

Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors (e.g., empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are preferred for diabetes management in patients with cardiac and renal failure due to their cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits.

  • Cardiovascular Benefits:
    • Reduce heart failure hospitalisation (especially in HF with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)).
    • Lower major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in high-risk patients.
  • Renal Benefits:
    • Slow progression of diabetic nephropathy.
    • Reduce albuminuria and preserve glomerular function.

Diabetic patients with heart failure best benefit from adding a group of drugs called SGLT-2 (sodium-glucose cotransporter-2) inhibitors, and empagliflozin falls in this group.

 

By inhibiting the SGLT-2 receptors in the proximal tubule of the kidneys, glucose (and sodium) reabsorption can be prevented.

 

Since both sodium and glucose are osmotic molecules, increasing their excretion draws out more water, making these drugs effective in patients with heart failure.

 

Drugs:

  • Dapagliflozin.
  • Empagliflozin.
  • Canagliflozin.
  • Ertugliflozin.

 

Side effects:

  • Infections (vaginal thrush, balanoposthitis, Fournier’s gangrene): Favour the growth of microbes in the lower urinary tract by providing an environment of excessive glucose.
  • Euglycemic ketoacidosis is due to inhibiting glucose reabsorption and the body’s preference for ketone bodies as an energy source after excess glucose excretion.
  • Osteoporosis: Rarely due to loss of calcium ions upon inhibition of the SGLT-2 receptors.

 

Pioglitazone (Option B) is incorrect because pioglitazone (a thiazolidinedione, TZD) causes fluid retention, worsening heart failure.

 

Metformin (Option C) is incorrect because although it is the first-line drug for type 2 diabetes, it is contraindicated in severe renal failure (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m²) due to the risk of lactic acidosis.

 

Sulfonylureas (Option D) is incorrect because sulfonylureas (e.g., glibenclamide, glipizide) increase hypoglycemia risk, especially in renal impairment due to reduced clearance.

questions.text: Edematous villi with chromosome XY was found. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A complete molar pregnancy is diploid (46,XX or 46,XY) and results from the fertilization of an empty ovum by either a single sperm that duplicates or by two sperms. Histopathological examination reveals diffusely edematous (swollen) villi with excessive trophoblastic proliferation and a complete absence of fetal tissue.

 

Feature

Partial Mole

Complete Mole

Karyotype

Usually 69, XXY or 69, XXX (triploid) (Option B ruled out)

Usually 46, XX or 46, XY (diploid)

Genetic origin

2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set

All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication)

Fetal tissue

It may be present but abnormal.

Absent.

β-hCG levels

Elevated, but lower than the complete mole

Very high

Risk of persistent GTD

5-10%

15-20%

Risk of choriocarcinoma

2-4%

2-3%

Theca lutein cysts

Less common

Common

HPE findings
  • Focal villous edema (some villi are normal, others are edematous)
  • Presence of fetal blood vessels in some villi.
  • Focal trophoblastic hyperplasia
  • Presence of fetal tissue (may include fetal red blood cells or embryonic/fetal parts).
  • Diffuse villous edema and hydropic swelling.
  • Absence of fetal blood vessels in villi
  • Marked atypical trophoblastic hyperplasia (both cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast).
  • No fetal tissue is present.

 

 

A cyst (Option C) may develop in the ovaries or placenta during pregnancy but does not exhibit edematous villi or chromosomal abnormalities like a molar pregnancy.


An ectopic pregnancy (Option D) occurs outside the uterus, does not exhibit molar villi, and lacks the characteristic hydropic changes seen in molar pregnancies.

questions.text: Which of the following drug dosages is incorrect for the treatment of leprosy in adults?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Rifampicin 450 mg

 

Explanation:

For leprosy treatment in adults, the correct dosage of Rifampicin is 600 mg monthly, not 450 mg.

The World Health Organization (WHO) Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) regimen for adults is:

  • Paucibacillary (PB) leprosy (6 months MDT):
    • Rifampicin 600 mg once monthly (supervised)
    • Dapsone 100 mg daily (self-administered)
  • Multibacillary (MB) leprosy (12 months MDT):
    • Rifampicin 600 mg once monthly (supervised)
    • Clofazimine 300 mg once monthly (supervised) + 50 mg daily (self-administered)
    • Dapsone 100 mg daily (self-administered)

Rifampicin 450 mg is incorrect because the standard dose for adults is 600 mg once monthly. However, 450 mg is used in children (10 mg/kg).

 

Characteristic

Paucibacillary

Multibacillary

Skin lesions

1-5 lesions

>5 lesions

Nerve involvement

No nerve

≥1 nerve involved

Slit skin smear

Negative

Positive

 

   

Treatment duration

Dapsone

Clofazimine

Rifampicin

Paucibacillary (PB)

Adult

6 months

100 mg daily

300 mg once a month & 50 mg daily

600 mg once a month

Child

(9-14 yrs)

6 months

50 mg daily

150 mg once a month & 50 mg alternate day

450 mg once a month

Multibacillary (MB)

Adult

12 months

100 mg daily

300 mg once a month & 50 mg daily

600 mg once a month

Child

(9-14 yrs)

12 months

50 mg daily

150 mg once a month & 50 mg alternate day

450 mg once a month

 

Single lesion paucibacillary:

  • One skin lesion with no nerve involvement.
  • In India: Treatment is similar to paucibacillary (Rifampicin, Dapsone, Clofazimine for 6 months)
  • According to WHO: ROM therapy
    • Rifampicin (600mg), Ofloxacin (400mg), Minocycline (100mg) - Single dose.
    • For a child, half of these adult doses are administered.

 

Drug-resistant leprosy Regimen
 

Intensive Phase (6 months)

Continuation Phase (18 months)

Rifampicin-resistant cases:

2 second line + 1 first line (Clofazimine)

Ofloxacin + Minocycline + Clofazimine

(or)

Ofloxacin + Clarithromycin + Clofazimine

Ofloxacin + Minocycline + Clofazimine

(or)

Ofloxacin + Clofazimine

Rifampicin & ofloxacin resistant cases

Clarithromycin + Minocycline + Clofazimine

(Clarithromycin or Minocycline) + Clofazimine

 

  • Dapsone 100 mg (Option A): Correct for both PB and MB leprosy.
  • Clofazimine 50 mg (Option B): Correct as a daily dose for MB leprosy.

 

  • Clofazimine 300 mg (Option C): Correct as a monthly supervised dose for MB leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not reversed with the administration of atropine?

choices.text: Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade

 

Explanation:

Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade is not reversed by atropine administration.

 

Atropine is an antimuscarinic (anticholinergic) agent that competitively blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It has no effect on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, which are responsible for skeletal muscle contraction. Therefore, atropine cannot reverse muscle weakness caused by neuromuscular blocking agents.

 

Atropine

Classification
  • Anticholinergic drug (Muscarinic receptor antagonist)
  • Competitive antagonist at muscarinic receptors

Mechanism of Action
  • Competitive inhibition of postganglionic acetylcholine muscarinic receptors
  • Blocks all subtypes of muscarinic receptors (M₁, M₂, M₃)
  • Direct vagolytic action leading to parasympathetic inhibition
  • Allows preexisting sympathetic stimulation to predominate

Pharmacological Actions

1. CNS Effects
  • Overall CNS stimulant action
  • Stimulates medullary centers (vagal, respiratory, vasomotor)
  • Depresses vestibular excitation (antimotion sickness property)
  • Suppresses tremor and rigidity in parkinsonism
  • High doses: cortical excitation, restlessness, hallucinations, delirium
  • Very high doses: respiratory depression and coma

2. CVS

Heart:

  • Tachycardia (primary effect) - blocks M₂ receptors on SA node (Option A Ruled Out)
  • Initial transient bradycardia may occur with IM/SC injection
  • Abbreviates refractory period of A-V node
  • Facilitates A-V conduction
  • Shortens P-R interval
 

Blood Pressure:

  • No consistent/marked effect on BP
  • Tachycardia and vasomotor center stimulation tend to raise BP
  • Histamine release and direct vasodilator action (at high doses) tend to lower BP
  • Blocks vasodepressor action of cholinergic agonists

3. Eye
  • Mydriasis (pupil dilation)
  • Cycloplegia (paralysis of accommodation)
  • Abolition of light reflex
  • Effects last 7-10 days with topical application
  • May increase intraocular tension, especially in narrow angle glaucoma
  • Has mild local anesthetic action on cornea

4. Smooth Muscles
  • Relaxes all visceral smooth muscles with parasympathetic innervation (M₃ blockade)
  • Reduces tone and amplitude of GI contractions
  • Slows passage of chyme; may cause constipation
  • Causes bronchodilation, reduces airway resistance (Option D Ruled Out)
  • Relaxes ureter and urinary bladder
  • Relaxation of biliary tract (less marked)
  • Minimal effect on uterus

5. Glandular Secretions
  • Markedly decreases sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lacrimal secretions (M₃ blockade) (Option C Ruled Out)

6. Body Temperature
  • Higher doses can cause rise in body temperature
  • Due to inhibition of sweating and stimulation of temperature regulating center
  • Children are highly susceptible to atropine fever

Relative Sensitivity of Organs

Decreasing order of sensitivity:

Saliva, sweat, bronchial secretion > eye, bronchial muscle, heart > smooth muscle of intestine, bladder > gastric glands and smooth muscle

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for severe acne?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is the most effective treatment for severe, nodulocystic, or treatment-resistant acne. It is a systemic retinoid that reduces sebum production, keratinization, and bacterial colonization, leading to long-term remission in many cases.

Acne Severity

Treatment Options

Mild Acne
  • Over-the-counter topical treatments (benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid)
  • Topical retinoids (adapalene) (Option A ruled out)

Moderate Acne
  • Topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)
  • Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline)
  • Topical retinoids (Option A ruled out)
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)

Severe Acne
  • Oral isotretinoin (Most effective) (Option B)
  • Oral antibiotics
  • Topical retinoids
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)
  • Intralesional corticosteroids (for cystic acne)


 

Other Options:

 

Steroids (Option C): Not used for acne treatment as systemic steroids can worsen acne (steroid-induced acne). Intralesional steroids can be used on a per lesion basis but is not the most appropriate treatment option to cure severe acne.


Antibiotics (Option D): Topical or oral antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline, clindamycin) are useful for inflammatory acne, but they are not as effective as isotretinoin for severe or resistant cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of sensation on the posterior surface of the ear along with a lesion. Which structure is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The Greater Auricular Nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2-C3) and provides sensory innervation to:

  • The posterior surface of the ear.
  • The skin over the angle of the mandible and parotid gland.
  • Part of the posterior auricular region.

Lesions affecting this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas.

 

Other options:

 

Internal Jugular Vein (Option B): A major venous structure that drains blood from the head and neck but does not contribute to sensory innervation.

 

External Jugular Vein (Option C): Also a venous structure, responsible for draining superficial areas of the head, but not involved in sensation.


External Carotid Artery (Option D): A major arterial supply to the face and scalp, but it does not play a role in sensory innervation.

questions.text: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with a punctured wound. Choose the correctmanagement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Local Treatment + RIG + Vaccine

Explanation: For a PLHIV with category III dog bites (multiple deep wounds), the correct management is local treatment, Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG), and the rabies vaccine.

Management of Dog Bite:

Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I
  • Touching or feeding animals
  • Licking of intact skin
  • Ensure proper hygiene
  • No treatment required

Category II
  • Nibbling on uncovered skin
  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

Rabies vaccination:

  • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
  • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III
  • Bites or scratches with bleeding
  • Licks on broken skin
  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.
  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.
  • Rabies vaccination:
    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):
    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

Required for unvaccinated individuals

Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of lower right abdominal pain and rebound tenderness in a patient with Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Appendicitis

 

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate acute appendicitis, despite the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Lower right abdominal pain with rebound tenderness is a classic sign of acute appendicitis, and the presence of a Meckel's diverticulum does not change this presentation. While Meckel's diverticulum can cause abdominal pain, the specific location and presence of rebound tenderness strongly suggest appendicitis as the primary pathology.

 

Perforation (Option A): While perforation of Meckel's diverticulum can occur, it typically presents with more diffuse abdominal pain and peritonitis rather than localized right lower quadrant pain. The presentation described is more consistent with appendicitis (Option A ruled out). Perforation would likely cause more widespread symptoms and signs of peritoneal irritation.

 

Intestinal obstruction (Option B): Meckel's diverticulum can cause intestinal obstruction, but this typically presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention rather than localized rebound tenderness (Option B ruled out). The absence of these obstruction symptoms makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Cholecystitis (Option D): Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, not lower right abdominal pain. The location of pain and the presence of rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant is inconsistent with cholecystitis (Option D ruled out). Murphy's sign would be expected in cholecystitis, which is elicited in the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: An image of the mascot is shown below. Identify the related national health.
questions.solution:
The mascot "Sapna" is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India.

  • NLEP Objectives:
    • Early detection and treatment of leprosy cases.
    • Promotion of Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) to prevent disabilities.
    • Reduction of social stigma associated with leprosy.
  • Key Initiative:
    • "Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign" (SLAC) focuses on community awareness, case detection, and inclusion of leprosy-affected individuals.

 

Primary Level of Prevention

  • Health Education
  • SPARSH program uses a cartoon girl known as Sapna who is in a village spreading awareness on Leprosy.

Secondary Level of Prevention

  • Early diagnosis and treatment
  • ASHA does detection
  • ASHA gets cash incentives

Tertiary Prevention

  • Treatment of drug-resistant leprosy
  • Disability limitation and rehabilitation
  • Reconstructive surgeries for deformities
  • Crutches to walk
  • Microcellular rubber footwear
  • Self-care kits

 

Sparsh program:

  • Create awareness about leprosy using Sapna as a mascot
  • Provides prophylaxis to close contacts
  • The concept of Sapna was adopted from Meena. It is for child rights and

Impairment given by UNICEF and was successful and adopted by Leprosy Trust Mission to

spread awareness.

 

SET Centres: (Survey, education and treatment centre): 1 SET centre / 25000 population

Attached to PHC.

 

Dose of rifampicin as prophylaxis (single dose):

≥ 15 years

600 mg

10-14 years

450 mg

6-9 years

300 mg

Children <20 kg

10-15 mg/kg

 

National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) (Option B): Associated with Nikshay Mitra and TB Champion campaigns, not Sapna.

National Anti-Malaria Programme (NAMP) (Option C): Focuses on malaria control and vector management, unrelated to leprosy.

National Polio Surveillance Programme (NPSP) (Option D): Uses polio mascots and the "Do Boond Zindagi Ki" campaign, not Sapna.

questions.text: A child presents with features of short stature, muscle weakness, and learning disability. Chromosome analysis reveals a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 15p on the paternal side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13, leading to the loss of genes that are normally expressed from the paternal allele. This occurs due to genomic imprinting, where the maternal allele is normally silenced, and the paternal allele is essential for normal function.

 

(Option A): Caused by a maternal deletion of chromosome 15q11-q13 (opposite of Prader-Willi Syndrome). Features include severe intellectual disability, ataxia, happy demeanor (frequent laughter), seizures, and microcephaly. UBE3A gene is affected.

 

(Option C): Caused by a deletion of chromosome 5p (5p- syndrome). Features include high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features.

 

(Option D): Caused by MECP2 gene mutations on the X chromosome (affects females almost exclusively). Features include neurodevelopmental regression, loss of purposeful hand movements (hand-wringing), ataxia, and seizures.

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra is via?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Venous spread

 

Explanation:

  • Prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to bones, especially the lumbar vertebrae.
  • Batson’s venous plexus (valveless vertebral venous system) connects the prostatic venous plexus to the vertebral column, providing a direct route for metastasis.
  • This system allows retrograde venous flow, especially in conditions of increased intra-abdominal pressure, facilitating spread to the lumbar spine.

Spread of Prostate Cancer

Route

Mechanism & Common Sites

Local spread

Direct extension into the seminal vesicles, bladder, or rectum

Lymphatic spread

Obturator, internal & external iliac nodes are commonly involved

Hematogenous spread

Via Batson’s venous plexus → lumbar vertebrae, pelvis, femur, ribs

Arterial spread

Rare, usually occurs late in disease progression

Arterial spread (Option A): Incorrect because arterial dissemination is rare in early prostate cancer and occurs mainly in advanced cases.

Local spread (Option B): Incorrect because local invasion affects seminal vesicles, bladder, and rectum, but does not explain vertebral metastasis.

Lymphatic spread (Option C): Incorrect because lymphatic metastasis affects pelvic nodes first (obturator, iliac) before distant sites.

questions.text: Which of the following changes occurs during muscle contraction while exercising?

choices.text: M length increase and I decrease

questions.solution:
Answer: C) I length decrease

 

Explanation:

During muscle contraction, the sarcomere shortens, leading to specific changes in the myofilament structure:

 

  • A-band: The length of the A-band remains the same during muscle contraction because it corresponds to the length of the myosin filaments, which do not change.
  • H-band: The H-band decreases or disappears as the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments during contraction, reducing the region where only myosin is present.
  • I-band: The length of the I-band decreases as the sarcomere shortens and the actin filaments overlap more with the myosin filaments.
  • M-line: The M-line becomes more prominent as it marks the central point of the sarcomere where the thick filaments are anchored.

 

 

M length increase (Option A) is incorrect because the M line does not change in length during contraction.

 

A length decrease (Option B) is incorrect because the A band remains constant (myosin filament length does not change).

 

M length increase and I decrease (Option D) is incorrect because while I band decreases, the M line does not change in length.

questions.text: All of the following are protected by OCPs except?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) do not provide protection against breast cancer. In fact, some studies suggest that long-term use of OCPs may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer, especially in women with other risk factors.


 

Adverse Effects of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Contraindications of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Cardiovascular Effects (due to estrogen content)

  • Myocardial infarction (MI)
  • Cerebral thrombosis - Stroke
  • Risk increases with age >35 and cigarette smoking.
 

Carcinogenesis

  • Increased risk of cervical cancer
 

Metabolic Effects (due to progesterone content)

  • Elevated blood pressure
  • Altered serum lipid levels
  • Interference with blood clotting
  • Interference with carbohydrate metabolism
 

Thromboembolic Events

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
  • Pulmonary embolism (PE)
 

Others

  • Lactation: Reduced quantity and quality of breast milk
  • Weight gain
  • Migraine
  • Breast tenderness

Absolute Contraindications:

  • Cancer of the breast and genitals
  • Liver disease
  • Previous or present history of thromboembolism
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Congenital hyperlipidaemia
 

Relative Contraindications (requiring medical surveillance):

  • Age over 40 years
  • Smoking and age over 35 years
  • Mild hypertension
  • Chronic renal disease
  • Migraine

 

Carcinoma endometrium (Option B) is incorrect because OCPs significantly reduce the risk of endometrial cancer by suppressing endometrial proliferation through progesterone action.

Colonic cancer (Option C) is incorrect because studies have shown that OCPs reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, although the exact mechanism is still being researched.

Ovarian cancer (Option D) is incorrect because OCPs provide strong protection against ovarian cancer by reducing ovulation frequency, which lowers the risk of malignant transformation in ovarian epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old person presented with an ulcer on the medial canthus. The ulcer has rolled-out, beaded margins. Histopathology shows nesting cells with peripheral palisading patterns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer and typically occurs in sun-exposed areas such as the face, particularly around the medial canthus of the eye.

The classic clinical description includes:

  • Ulceration with rolled-out, beaded margins.
  • A pearly or translucent appearance with visible telangiectasia.

Histopathology findings include:

  • Nesting of basaloid cells.
  • Peripheral palisading of nuclei.
  • Clefting artifact between tumor cells and surrounding stroma.

Other Options:

 

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) (Option A): Typically presents with a scaly, keratinized lesion that may ulcerate but lacks the rolled, pearly margins and palisading pattern seen in BCC.

 

Nevus (Option B): A benign lesion that does not typically ulcerate or have invasive histological features.


Melanoma (Option D): Usually presents with irregular pigmentation, asymmetry, and rapid growth, rather than a rolled-margin ulcer.

questions.text: After how long is a patient advised to use alternative contraception following a vasectomy?
questions.solution:
Sterility after vasectomy is typically achieved within 3 months or after 20 ejaculations, whichever occurs later. Until then, an alternative method of contraception is required.

 

Vasectomy is a safe, minimally invasive, and highly effective method of male sterilization.

  • The no-scalpel technique, which involves a small puncture instead of a traditional incision, is now widely used and associated with fewer complications.
  • The vas deferens, the tube responsible for transporting sperm, is divided during the procedure.
  • Sperm present in the post-distal ligation area can lead to pregnancy, hence contraception is required for 3 months or 20 ejaculations, whichever is later.
  • Sterilization is confirmed by semen analysis, with at least 2 analyses showing azoospermia.

Studies show that 80% of men are sterile after 15 ejaculations or about 6 weeks, and 89% are sperm-free by 10 weeks. The remaining sperm is gradually cleared, making the safe time period approximately 3 months.

questions.text: A woman with forceps delivery 24 hours ago presents with pain in the perineum. Her BP is 80/60 and on examination, there is a swelling with bluish discolouration. Which of the following steps are advised not to do?

choices.text: Repair the wound in the ward

questions.solution:
A woman who had a forceps delivery 24 hours ago presents with perineal pain, hypotension (BP: 80/60 mmHg), and bluish perineal swelling, indicating an actively bleeding postpartum vulvar hematoma. The presence of hypotension suggests ongoing blood loss and impending shock, necessitating urgent intervention.

Attempting wound repair in the ward is not suitable, as it fails to achieve adequate hemostasis and increases the risk of recurrent bleeding and complications. Delaying surgical intervention can lead to worsening maternal morbidity and mortality.

Postpartum spontaneous vulvar hematoma is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication, commonly associated with instrumental deliveries such as forceps or vacuum-assisted births. It occurs due to trauma to the labial branches of the internal pudendal artery, leading to a localized blood collection in the vulvar or perineal region. If left untreated, the hematoma can expand rapidly, resulting in severe hemorrhage, anemia, and hemodynamic instability.

Management Approach

The immediate priority in such cases is:

  • Surgical exploration in the OT for hematoma evacuation and bleeding vessel ligation (Option C)
  • Blood transfusion for hemodynamic stabilization (Option B)

Involvement of a senior obstetrician for expert management (Option D)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant

 

Explanation:

Treatment of DVT:

Anticoagulation: For initial management of acute DVT without contraindications to anticoagulation, the current recommended approach is to start with LMWH and transition to an oral anticoagulant.

This approach has several advantages:

  • LMWH provides rapid anticoagulation without the need for monitoring.
  • Oral anticoagulants have shown non-inferiority or superiority to warfarin in large clinical trials. They have a better safety profile and do not require regular INR monitoring.
  • This regimen allows for outpatient management in many cases, reducing hospitalization rates.

Investigation of DVT:

Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning

Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins.

  • Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein
  • Absence of compressibility
  • Absence of blood flow

Venogram

Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness.

Impedance Plethysmography

Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis.

Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays

Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer.

D-dimer has a high negative predictive value.

Radioactive Fibrinogen Study

Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used.

Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI)

Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC.

 

Management of DVT :

Initial Anticoagulation
  • Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases.
  • Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment.
  • Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Transition to Oral Anticoagulation
  • Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence.
  • Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor).
  • Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs).

Monitoring Anticoagulation
  • Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT).
  • Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0.

For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation

Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D)

Endovascular Surgery
  • Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting.
  • Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post-thrombotic syndrome.

 

Unfractionated heparin followed by warfarin (Option A) was the traditional approach.

  • But it has largely been superseded by LMWH and DOACs due to the need for hospitalization, frequent aPTT monitoring for unfractionated heparin, and long-term INR monitoring for warfarin.

 

Catheter-directed thrombolysis (Option C) is generally reserved for massive iliofemoral DVT with severe symptoms or limb-threatening situations.

  • It carries a higher risk of bleeding and is not first-line therapy for most DVT cases.

questions.text: Which of the following health programmes supports DANIDA?
questions.solution:
DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) has supported the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India, focusing on cataract surgery, training of eye care professionals, and infrastructure development.


 

Agencies

Headquarters

Services in India

United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

Washington
  • Malaria eradication
  • Medical and nursing education
  • Health education
  • Water supply and sanitation
  • Nutrition and Family Planning
  • Control of Communicable Diseases

Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA)

Sweden

Assisting the National TB Control Program

Danish International Development Agency (DANIDA)

Denmark

Assisting the National Blindness Control Programme.

 

Image 2- SIDA

Image 3- DANIDA

TB (Option A) is incorrect because TB control in India has been supported by organisations like the World Health Organization (WHO), SIDA, Global Fund, and USAID, but not primarily by DANIDA.

Malaria (Option C) is incorrect because malaria control efforts have been supported by WHO, USAID, Global Fund, and World Bank, rather than DANIDA.

HIV (Option D) is incorrect because HIV/AIDS programmes in India are supported by UNAIDS, WHO, NACO, and the Global Fund, but not by DANIDA.

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of diabetes presents with cataracts. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation in this condition?
questions.solution:
• In individuals with diabetes, high blood glucose levels can lead to increased activity of the enzyme aldose reductase. This enzyme converts glucose to sorbitol.
  • Sorbitol is poorly metabolized and can accumulate within the lens of the eye.
  • The accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes, drawing water into the lens and causing it to swell. This swelling and disruption of lens fibers leads to cataract formation.

 

Pathophysiology of Diabetic Cataract Formation:

  1. Glucose enters the lens (insulin-independent uptake).
  2. Aldose reductase converts glucose → sorbitol .
  3. Sorbitol accumulates (since its conversion to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase is slow in the lens).
  4. Sorbitol is osmotically active, causing lens swelling, oxidative stress, and crystallin protein aggregation → cataract formation.


 

Mannitol (Option A): Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is not involved in cataract formation.

 

Galactitol (Option B): Galactitol (dulcitol) accumulates in the lens in galactosemia, leading to early-onset cataracts, but not in diabetic cataracts.

 

Fructose (Option D): While sorbitol is eventually converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase, the rate is slow in the lens, making sorbitol the primary culprit in diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: A married female died in unnatural condition within 3 years of marriage. Her father filed a report to police and inquiry will be done under which section?
questions.solution:
In cases of a married woman's unnatural death within 7 years of marriage, a Magistrate-led inquiry is mandatory under Section 176 CrPC (or Section 196 BNSS). This ensures a thorough and impartial investigation, especially when foul play, suicide, or dowry-related violence is suspected.

 

In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest.

 

1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS)

  • Most common type of inquest in India.
  • Conducted by a police officer, generally not below the rank of Head Constable.

The police officer, upon receiving information about the unnatural death, visits the site.

↓

Involves two or more witnesses from the local area, called panchas, to assist in the investigation. The report is referred to as a panchnama.

↓

If the cause of death appears to be accidental or non-suspicious, the body is handed over to the family for funeral proceedings.

↓

In case of suspicious circumstances, the police officer forwards the body for a postmortem to a certified medical officer and sends the report to the Magistrate.

 

2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS)

  • Conducted by an Executive Magistrate, or Judicial Magistrate.
  • It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including:
    • Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody or any custody authorized by the court
    • Deaths due to police firing
    • Deaths in jail
    • Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if,
      • Commits suicide
      • In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence
      • Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf
      • There is any doubt regarding the cause of death
    • Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death
    • Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request
  • Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation
  • An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate.
  • The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death.

 

Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests:

Feature

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

Conducted by

Police officer

Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate)

Involvement of witnesses

Requires signatures of panchas

Does not require witness signatures

Witness statements

Admissible in court

Not admissible in court

Can order arrest

No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses

Can issue arrest warrants

Exhumation

Cannot order exhumation

Can order exhumation of a body

Autopsy orders

Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately

Orders autopsy only when necessary

Forensic analysis

Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera

Can order chemical analysis

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was admitted to ICU with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media by Staphylococcus aureus. Blood test shows decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, and plasma B cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bruton syndrome

Explanation

The decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, plasma B cells and the recurrent infections suggest the diagnosis of Bruton syndrome which is an X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Brutons’s Disease:

  • Also Known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) caused by mutations in the BTK (Bruton’s tyrosine kinase) gene present on the q22 long arm of the X chromosome.
  • Defective B-cell maturation leads to an absence of mature B cells and very low levels of all immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM).
  • Clinical features: Presents after 6-9 months of age. Recurrent bacterial infections (eg- encapsulated bacteria like Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus influenzae) starting around 6 months of age including otitis media, pneumonia, and sinusitis, Neutropenia and enterovirus infections.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Absence of B cells (CD19+ cells) in peripheral blood and
    • Markedly low immunoglobulin levels
    • No germinal centres in lymph nodes

Ataxia-Telangiectasia (Option A) is characterized by cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency. The immunodeficiency is variable with low immunoglobulins and T cells. There is common IgA deficiency (selective absence of IgA in 50-80 %); impaired T- and B-cell responses; and small, disorganized thymus.

Chronic granulomatous disease (Option B) is due to the reduced activity of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase, leading to impaired generation of superoxide radicals. It presents with persistent smouldering pneumonia, prominent lymphadenitis, multiple liver abscesses, osteomyelitis of small bones of hands and feet, recurrent, life-threatening infections usually by catalase-positive bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia) and fungi (e.g., Aspergillus)

DiGeorge syndrome (Option D) is caused by microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2 and presents with cardiac anomalies, abnormal facies, thymic hypoplasia/ aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemic tetany.

questions.text: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bacillus cereus

Explanation: Bacillus cereus causes rapid-onset vomiting (within 1–6 hours) after consuming contaminated fried rice.

Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus:

Clinical Features

Details


 

Food Poisoning
  • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic.
  • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion.
  • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare)
  • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours.
  • Some cases may include diarrhoea

Other Infections
  • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis
  • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients

Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus:

Diagnostic Method

Details

Food Poisoning
  • Culture of implicated food essential.
  • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis.
  • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis.

Culture Characteristics
  • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar.
  • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance.
  • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin

Selective Media
  • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources

Microscopy
  • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Motile

Clostridium botulinum (Option B) causes botulism, presenting with descending paralysis and no vomiting, with symptoms appearing 12–36 hours after ingestion.

Escherichia coli (Option C): ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli) causes watery diarrhea, not isolated vomiting, and has a longer incubation period (12–72 hours).


Shigella dysenteriae (Option D): Causes bloody diarrhea (dysentery) with fever, not acute vomiting.

questions.text: Under IDSP, which diseases are included under sentinel surveillance?
questions.solution:
Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) in India, sentinel surveillance is conducted for specific diseases to monitor trends and inform public health interventions. According to the IDSP guidelines, the diseases included under sentinel surveillance are:

  • HIV/AIDS: Monitored through designated sentinel sites to track prevalence and trends.
  • Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): Included in sentinel surveillance to assess infection rates and inform public health strategies.
  • Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs): Other STIs are also monitored to understand their epidemiology and control measures.


 

HIV + TB (Option B): Incorrect. While HIV is under sentinel surveillance, tuberculosis (TB) is monitored through regular surveillance mechanisms, not sentinel surveillance.

Malaria + Dengue (Option C): Incorrect. Both malaria and dengue are vector-borne diseases monitored under regular surveillance, not sentinel surveillance.

Measles + Diphtheria (Option D): Incorrect. These vaccine-preventable diseases are also monitored through regular surveillance rather than sentinel surveillance.

questions.text: During spermatogenesis, which of the following hormones inhibits Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) secretion?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Inhibin

 

Explanation:

Inhibin is the primary hormone that inhibits Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) secretion during spermatogenesis.

 

Function of Sertoli cells:

  • Only Sertoli cells form the blood-testis barrier
  • Nourishment and protection to developing sperm cells.
  • Sertoli cells contain receptors for FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and androgens, which indirectly support spermatogenesis.
  • Sertoli cells produce androgen-binding protein (ABP).
  • Sertoli cells express the aromatase enzyme, responsible for converting testosterone to estrogen.
  • They produce extracellular matrix components and anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH/MIS), which induces regression of Müllerian ducts during male fetal development.
  • Sertoli cells secrete Inhibin B, a crucial factor in the testes that negatively regulates (decreases) FSH secretion through feedback mechanisms.

 

Testosterone (Option A) is incorrect because testosterone primarily inhibits LH secretion by acting on the hypothalamus and pituitary. However, it does not directly inhibit FSH.

 

Luteinizing Hormone (LH) (Option C) is incorrect because LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, but it does not inhibit FSH secretion.

 

Androgen (Option D) is incorrect because androgens (like testosterone) primarily regulate LH via negative feedback, not FSH directly.

questions.text: In a class of 100 students, 80% students were immunised with measles, 12 were affected. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
The Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is calculated using the formula:

 

SAR(%)=(Number of secondary cases​ / Number of susceptible individuals) × 100

Given:

  • Total students = 100
  • 80% immunised → 20% susceptible
  • Susceptible students = 20% of 100 = 20
  • 12 students were affected (secondary cases)

Substituting the values:

SAR(%) = (12 / 20​) × 100 = 60%

questions.text: A young female has episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. Which of the following acid- base disturbace is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The patient exhibits binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, which is characteristic of bulimia nervosa. Recurrent vomiting leads to loss of gastric acid (HCl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. This occurs because:

  1. Loss of hydrogen ions (H⁺) through vomiting leads to an increase in blood pH (alkalosis).
  2. Loss of chloride (Cl⁻) contributes to hypochloremia, which further impairs bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) excretion, worsening alkalosis.
  3. Hypokalemia often accompanies metabolic alkalosis due to renal compensation, where the kidneys excrete more H⁺ in exchange for potassium (K⁺).

 

Binge Eating Episodes
  • Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.

Compensatory Behaviors
  • Purging behaviors (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise.

BMI
  • Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).

Physical Signs
  • Parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears)

These signs appear due to repeated purging.

Electrolyte Disturbances
  • Commonly hypokalemia and hypochloremia.

Metabolic Changes
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting.

Physical Findings
  • Dorsal hand calluses from induced vomiting (Russell sign).

 


 

Other Options:

 

Respiratory acidosis (Option A): This occurs due to hypoventilation (e.g., in chronic lung disease), leading to CO₂ retention and a drop in pH. Vomiting does not cause respiratory acidosis.

 

Respiratory alkalosis (Option B) : Caused by hyperventilation (e.g., anxiety, panic attacks) leading to excess CO₂ loss, but vomiting does not affect breathing.

 

Metabolic acidosis (Option C): Seen in conditions such as diarrhea, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), or renal failure, where there is an excess loss of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) or acid buildup. Vomiting removes acid rather than increasing it, making metabolic acidosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with fever, rash, and Bitot spots. What is the appropriate line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Only Vitamin A Supplementation

Explanation:

  • The child already has measles, so the priority is to address the vitamin A deficiency (as evidenced by Bitot spots) to reduce the risk of complications and support recovery.
  • The measles vaccine is not required at this stage because the child has already been infected and will develop lifelong immunity.

Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature)
 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.
 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

Measles Rash

Measles Vaccine + Vitamin A Supplementation (Option A): The measles vaccine is not needed after measles infection, as the child will have lifelong immunity. The vaccine is for prevention, not for post-infection management.

Only Measles Vaccine (Option B): The vaccine is unnecessary post-infection, and vitamin A supplementation is critical in this case.

Supportive Care (Option D): While supportive care is part of the management, it does not address the important need for vitamin A supplementation in a measles case.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is taking indomethacin and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What potential side effect is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

The combination of indomethacin (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, NSAID) and an ACE inhibitor increases the risk of hyperkalemia due to their combined effects on renal function and potassium homeostasis.

  • Mechanism:
    • ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril, lisinopril) block angiotensin-converting enzymes, reducing aldosterone secretion.
    • Aldosterone promotes potassium excretion, so reduced aldosterone leads to potassium retention.
    • Indomethacin (NSAID) further reduces renal perfusion by inhibiting prostaglandins, worsening potassium retention.
    • This can lead to hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), dehydration, or concurrent diuretic use.

 

Drug Interaction

Mechanism

Clinical Implication

ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K-sparing diuretics

Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents.

Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias.

ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs

NSAIDs can reduce the anti-hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria.

Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high-risk patients.

ACE Inhibitors + Lithium

ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity.

Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed.

ACE Inhibitors + Antacids

Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids.

Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy.

ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics

Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels.

In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially.

 

  • Hypercalcemia (Option B) is incorrect because neither NSAIDs nor ACE inhibitors cause significant calcium elevation. ACE inhibitors may slightly lower calcium levels by increasing urinary calcium excretion.

 

  • Hypernatremia (Option C) is incorrect because ACE inhibitors do not cause sodium retention; instead, they promote mild natriuresis (sodium excretion).

 

  • Hyperphosphatemia (Option D) is incorrect because NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors do not directly affect phosphate metabolism; hyperphosphatemia is more commonly seen in CKD due to decreased phosphate excretion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. He has a history of perineal trauma. On examination, blood is noted at the external urethral meatus. Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Bulbar urethra

 

Explanation:

  • Patient presentation:
    • Severe urinary urgency but inability to void → Suggests urethral obstruction.
    • History of perineal injury → Strongly suggests trauma to the anterior urethra.
    • Blood at the meatus → A classic sign of urethral injury.
  • Bulbar urethral injury is common in perineal trauma:
    • Common mechanism: Straddle injuries (e.g., fall on a hard surface).
    • Bulbar urethra is vulnerable due to its location in the anterior urethra.
    • Extravasation of urine may be seen if severe.

Urethral Injuries

Urethral Segment

Common Causes of Injury

Clinical Features

Bulbar urethra (Anterior)

Straddle injuries, blunt perineal trauma

Blood at meatus, urinary retention, perineal hematoma

Membranous urethra (Posterior)

Pelvic fractures

High-riding prostate, inability to pass urine

Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture

Blunt abdominal trauma

Peritonitis, urinary ascites

Posterior Urethral Valve

Congenital anomaly

Recurrent UTIs, voiding difficulty

Posterior urethral valve (Option B): Incorrect because it is a congenital condition seen in infants, not in a previously healthy young adult.

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with peritonitis and urinary ascites, not blood at the meatus or perineal trauma.

Membranous urethra (Option D): Incorrect because it is typically injured in pelvic fractures, which are not mentioned in the history.

questions.text: A 30-year-old met with a bike accident and presented with the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a lengthened limb with external rotation and abduction, which is characteristic of anterior hip dislocation.

 

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.


 

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

 

Mechanism of injury:
 

Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

 

 

  

 

 

 


 

Posterior Hip Dislocation (Option B): Would present with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation (not seen here).

Superior Hip Dislocation (Option C): Very rare, associated with high-energy trauma and pelvic fractures.

Both A and B (Option D): The presentation is specific to anterior dislocation only.

questions.text: A forensic expert received a summons from the district court to record his evidence in a criminal case, but two days prior, he already received a summons for a civil case in the same district court for the same date. What should the doctor do?

choices.text: Attend the court for which the summons came first.
Attend the court for the criminal case.

questions.solution:
• Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases due to their public importance and urgency.
  • The forensic expert must attend the criminal case and inform the civil court about the conflict, requesting a rescheduled date.
  • Ignoring a court summons can lead to legal consequences, so prioritizing the criminal case is mandatory.

 

Summons/Subpoena:

  • A subpoena is a legal order mandating a witness to appear before a court on a specific date, time, and location to provide testimony or evidence, under penalty.
  • A subpoena is issued by the court in writing, signed by the presiding officer, and carries the court's official seal (Sec. 63 BNSS).
  • Delivered to the witness by a police officer, court official, or public servant.
  • The witness must sign and return a duplicate copy of the subpoena to acknowledge receipt (Sec. 64 BNSS).

 

Types of Subpoenas

  1. Subpoena duces tecum:
    • The witness is required to bring specific documents or items to the court (e.g., medico-legal reports or postmortem findings).
    • For expert witness.
  2. Subpoena ad testificandum:
    • The witness is required to appear in court to provide oral testimony.
    • For common witnesses.

 

Punishment for Failing to Comply with a Subpoena/Summons:

1. Civil Cases:

  • The witness may be ordered to pay damages for failing to attend court. This involves compensation for the inconvenience caused to the parties involved in the case.

2. Criminal Cases:

If a witness fails to appear in court without a justified reason, the following actions can be taken:

  • Under 63 – 71 BNSS, the court may issue a notice to the witness to explain their absence.
  • The court may issue notice under Section 389, BNSS and after hearing the witness, if it finds that the witness neglected to attend the court without a justified reason, may punish him under Section 208 and 209, BNS, and sentence him/her to:
    • A fine (Rs.1000/-), OR
    • Imprisonment (6 months), OR
    • Both fine and imprisonment.
  • Also, the Court may issue bailable or non-bailable warrants to secure the presence of the witness (S.206 to 209, BNS and S.90, BNSS).

 

Prioritization of Summons:

  • Criminal vs. Civil Courts: If a witness is summoned by both criminal and civil courts for the same day, they must attend the criminal court, which takes precedence.
  • Higher vs. Lower Courts: When summoned by two courts of the same jurisdiction (e.g., civil or criminal), the witness must attend the higher court first.
  • Multiple Summons: If the witness receives multiple summonses from the same type of court, they should attend the court that issued the first summons and notify the other.

 

Inform both courts and wait (Option A): While informing both courts is a good step, simply waiting without attending either court is not advisable, as it could lead to legal consequences.

 

Attend the court for which the summons came first (Option B): The order in which the summons were received does not determine priority. The nature of the case (criminal vs. civil) takes precedence.

 

Do not attend either court (Option D): Ignoring court summons can result in contempt of court or other legal penalties.

questions.text: Which of the following is the afferent limb of the corneal reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trigeminal nerve
 

Explanation:

The corneal reflex (blink reflex) involves two components:

  1. Afferent limb (sensory input):
    • The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) detects touch or irritation on the cornea and sends sensory signals to the brainstem.
  2. Efferent limb (motor response):
    • The facial nerve (CN VII) activates the orbicularis oculi muscle, causing eyelid closure.

 

Reflex

Afferent Nerve

Efferent Nerve

Accommodation

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

Corneal

V₁ (Ophthalmic, nasociliary branch)

Bilateral VII (Facial nerve, temporal branch - orbicularis oculi)

Cough

X (Vagus nerve)

X (Vagus nerve, also phrenic and spinal nerves)

Gag

IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

X (Vagus nerve)

Jaw Jerk

V₃ (Mandibular branch, sensory from masseter)

V₃ (Mandibular branch, motor to masseter)

Lacrimation

V₁ (Ophthalmic branch) (loss of reflex does not preclude emotional tears)

VII (Facial nerve)

Pupillary

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

 

Optic nerve (Option A): Involved in the pupillary light reflex, not the corneal reflex.

Facial nerve (Option B): Acts as the efferent limb, responsible for blinking, not the afferent limb.

Trochlear nerve (Option D): Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which controls eye movement but has no role in the corneal reflex.

The condenser lens needs to be kept close to the eye.
