questions.text: A patient’s laboratory results were positive for malarial antigen, and the Widal test findings were as follows: O ag >1:300, H ag >1:20, A >1:20, B >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Recent infection by Salmonella spp

Explanation: A significantly elevated O antigen titer (>1:300) only in the Widal test suggests a recent Salmonella infection.

Widal Test:

  • It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi.
  • It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • The test is based on the agglutination reaction where patient serum is mixed with antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • If the antibodies are present, they will cause the antigens to clump together (agglutinate), indicating a positive result.
  • The test primarily measures:
    • O-antibodies: These are antibodies against the somatic (O) antigens of Salmonella typhi.
    • H-antibodies: These are antibodies against the flagellar (H) antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • Antigens Used:
    • O antigen of S. Typhi (TO)
    • H antigen of S. Typhi (TH)
    • H antigen of S. Paratyphi A (AH)
    • H antigen of S. Paratyphi B (BH)
  • Interpretation:
    • Cut-off values in most parts of India:
      • H agglutinin titer >200.
      • O agglutinin titer >100.
    • Low titers: Considered baseline in endemic areas and should be ignored.

Widal Test Result

Suggestive of

Rise of TO and TH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Typhi

Rise of TO and AH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi A

Rise of TO and BH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi B

Rise of only TO antibody

Recent infection due to S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi A or B

Rise of only TH antibody

Convalescent stage / Anamnestic response

Rise of all TH, AH, BH

Post-TAB vaccination antibodies (Option B)

Past infection (Option C): A past infection usually results in elevated H antigen titers, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer is significantly high, indicating a recent infection.

Reconvalescence (Option D): In the recovery phase, both O and H antigen titers decline, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer remains markedly high, supporting a recent infection instead.

questions.text: A young man with a psychiatric disorder has become very aggressive. He speaks very rapidly and sleeps very little. He exhibits hyperactive behavior after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, including aggression, rapid speech, decreased need for sleep, and hyperactivity, strongly suggest a manic episode. Manic episodes are characterized by elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, impulsivity, distractibility, and decreased need for sleep, typically lasting at least one week. The fact that these symptoms worsened after discontinuing prescribed medication further supports the diagnosis, as stopping mood stabilizers or antipsychotics can trigger a manic relapse.


 

Bipolar disorder

 

  • Bipolar disorder is a type of mood disorder characterized by episodes of depression, mania, hypomania, mixed episodes.
  • Even a single episode of mania is considered bipolar disorder.
  • ICD-11 classifies only two types of bipolar disorder.

 

Bipolar I Disorder

Bipolar II Disorder

Characterized by at least 1 episode of mania and 1 episode of depression

Characterized by at least 1 episode of hypomania and 1 episode of depression (Option B)

M=F

F>M

Mean age of onset is 30yrs

Mean age of onset is slightly higher


 

Diagnostic criteria for Mania
  • Mood Changes: Elation/ irritability

+ ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if irritable mood) for at least 1 week:

  • Distractibility.
  • Impulsivity/ high-risk activities
  • Grandiosity/ Inflated Self-Esteem
  • Flight of Ideas (Racing and expansive thoughts)
  • Activity increased (Hyperactivity)
  • Sleep deficit (decreased need for sleep)
  • Talkativeness/ Pressured speech

 

Mania with Psychotic Symptoms:

  • May include delusions or hallucinations.
  • Can be mood-congruent or mood-incongruent.

Mood-congruent: When psychotic symptoms are mood-congruent, the content of a person’s delusions or hallucinations aligns with the person’s mood state.

Mood-incongruent: The content of a person’s delusions or hallucinations does not match their mood.

 

Other Options:

 

Depression (Option A): This condition typically presents with low mood, fatigue, decreased energy, and sleep disturbances, but not hyperactivity, aggression, or rapid speech. The patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of mania rather than a depressive episode.

 

Schizophrenia (Option C): While schizophrenia can involve disorganized speech and behavior, it is primarily characterized by delusions, hallucinations, and cognitive impairment, which are not mentioned in this case. The episodic nature of the patient’s symptoms also favors bipolar disorder over schizophrenia.


Substance-Induced Mood Disorder (Option D): While certain drugs (e.g., stimulants) can cause hyperactivity and aggression, there is no mention of substance use, withdrawal, or intoxication in the case history, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chancroid

 

Explanation:

 

A painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy in a sexually active adult is highly suggestive of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Feature Chancroid
Causative organism Haemophilus ducreyi
Incubation period 3–10 days
Ulcer Painful, non-indurated, soft ulcer with irregular borders and granular base
Number of ulcers Often multiple
Lymphadenopathy Painful, unilateral or bilateral, may form buboes (fluctuant lymph nodes)
Base of ulcer Necrotic, purulent, bleeds on contact
Tenderness Marked

 

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae Infection (Option B): Causes urethritis, cervicitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), but not painful genital ulcers.

 

Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) (Option C): Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that slowly enlarge and lack lymphadenopathy. Donovan bodies seen on microscopy.

 

Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV) (Option D): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serotypes). Typically presents with small, painless ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), which can lead to groove sign (inguinal ligament indentation).

questions.text: A villager was assaulted by 4-5 people & brought to hospital in serious condition. His dying declaration was being taken in hospital. What is correct regarding this process?

choices.text: Oath is compulsory before recording the statement

questions.solution:
• Ideally, a Magistrate should record the dying declaration to ensure authenticity and legality.
  • In exceptional cases, when a Magistrate is unavailable and death is imminent, a doctor or even a police officer may record the statement

 

Dying Declaration vs Dying Deposition

Feature

Dying Declaration

Dying Deposition

Recorder

Anyone—Magistrate/doctor/village headman/police/any member of the public

Always recorded by a Magistrate

Oath (Option D)

Not required

Must be taken

Accused or his counsel

Not present

Always present

Cross-examination

Not done

Done

Legal value

Comparatively less

Much more

Admissibility if declarant survives

Not admitted, but has corroborative value

Fully admitted

Nature

Merely recording of statement

Complete court procedure

Type of evidence

Documentary

Oral

Status in India

Followed

Not followed

Leading Qs (Option C)

Not Permitted

Permitted

Doctor can record the statement (Option B): Not ideal.

  • A doctor can record the dying declaration only if a Magistrate is unavailable and death is imminent.
  • However, the Magistrate is the preferred authority for legal validity.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. Which radiological sign is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rat-tail sign

Explanation:

 

  • Dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids suggests achalasia, a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • Achalasia is characterized by failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, leading to progressive dilation of the esophagus with tapering at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • On barium swallow, achalasia classically shows a "Rat-tail sign"—a smooth, gradual narrowing at the distal esophagus due to the non-relaxing LES.

  • Radiological Signs in Esophageal Disorders

    Radiological Sign

    Associated Condition

    Appearance

    Rat-tail sign (Correct Answer)

    Achalasia

    Smooth tapering of the esophagus at the LES

    Filling defect

    Esophageal tumors, strictures

    Irregular defect in the barium column

    Corkscrew esophagus

    Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)

    Multiple non-peristaltic contractions creating a "corkscrew" pattern

    Apple-core lesion

    Esophageal or colonic cancer

    Constricted lumen with irregular edges, resembling an apple core
     

    Filling defect (Option B) is incorrect because a filling defect is a non-specific radiological finding seen in conditions like oesophageal tumours, varices, or strictures. It does not typically present with dysphagia that is worse for liquids.

     

    Corkscrew oesophagus (Option C) is incorrect because it is seen in diffuse oesophageal spasm (DES), which presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia for both solids and liquids, rather than a progressive pattern.


    Apple-core lesion (Option D) is incorrect because it is a characteristic finding in colorectal cancer, not an oesophageal disorder.

questions.text: What is the most common causative organism of prosthetic heart valve endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis (a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus) is the most common cause of prosthetic heart valve endocarditis (PVE)

 

CONS (Coagulase negative staphylococcus):

  • Normal flora of the human body
  • S. epidermidis, S.haemolyticus, and S.lugdunensis cause device-associated and healthcare-associated infections.
  • The most frequent cause of CoNS infections in people is S. epidermidis.
  • It causes biofilm formation and prosthetic heart valve infection( <12 months post-replacement)
  • It is normal skin flora and causes illness when the host's defenses are compromised. It frequently results in stitch abscesses.


 

S. viridans (Option A): Common in native valve endocarditis, especially after dental procedures, but not the most common in prosthetic valves.

 

S. aureus (Option B): Can cause acute PVE, especially in IV drug users, but S. epidermidis is more common overall in prosthetic valves.

Staphylococcus (Option D): Too broad—Does not specify S. epidermidis, which is the most common cause of PVE.
